item.title: Planning Your Pathway to College
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Going to college is a process. And it takes some work to find the right path for you. Fortunately, there are some great website resources that can help you figure it all out.

  • A Free Guide Showing You The Way

    Philadelphia Futures is a non-profit organization that helps prepare students for college. Each year, they publish a free “Step Up To College” Guide. Click here and you can look through the guide on-line or print out a copy of your own.These free guides are also available in schools, libraries and community organizations. Inside the guide is information on what courses you need to take in high school to apply to college, how to organize your college search, information on standardized tests and financial aid among other useful topics.

  • A Free Resource on The Right Way to Apply to College

    The Office of College and Career Awareness of the School District of Philadelphia provides resources to students, school staff, parents and the community to achieve academic and career success. You don’t even have to attend a Philadelphia public school to take advantage of this free resource. Click here to go to their website and get comprehensive information on high school classes needed to apply to college, college prep workshops, financial aid information, scholarship listings and more.

  • Elementary and Middle School Students, Get Ready for College Now!

    Its never to early to get ready for college, even if you are in middle school or elementary school.

    The classes you choose to take now will effect how prepared you are for college. click here to for information on what classes you should take to prepare for college.

    You can also prepare for college by planning for high school. In Philadelphia you can attend your neighborhood high school or apply to a different type of high school. You can use the two websites below to learn more about different high schools. Click here for information on how to apply for public high schools, and click here for information on applying to charter and private high schools.

    For more information on choosing a high school check out the Philadelphia Public School Notebook's High School Guide.

  • Track Your Progress

    If you attend a school operated by the School District of Philadelphia you can log on to StudentNet to view your grades, the classes you've taken, and your test scores. Click here to log on and track your progress!

  • Getting Practical Advice From Students Already On Their Way

    KnowHow2Go is a campaign sponsored by the American Council on Education, the Lumina Foundation for Education and the Ad Council to help students in middle school through 12th grade prepare for college.

    Click here to go to their website for financial advice, career options and scholarship information.

  • Getting Expert Advice When Thinking, Choosing or Paying for College

    EducationPlanner.org is a comprehensive website sponsored by American Education Services (AES) which is a non-profit organization and is among the nation's leading providers of student financial aid services. Click here to find out how they can help you plan your path to college.

    College Access Centers

    If you’re in high school, the Philadelphia Education Fund has three College Access Centers open in three areas of the City to provide students with free help with the college application process, financial aid, scholarships and other things. All students are welcome at these sites:

    • The Gallery I, Street Level – Center City
      9th and Market Streets
      Philadelphia, PA 19107
      215.574.1341
      Open Monday – Thursday, 10 am – 6 pm; Friday 10 am – 5 pm
    • The Enterprise Center – West Philadelphia
      4548 Market Street
      Philadelphia, PA 19139
      215.476.2227
      Open Monday – Friday, 9 am – 5 pm
    • Rivera Building – North Philadelphia
      2603 N. 5th Street
      Philadelphia, PA 19133
      215.739.9360
      Open Monday – Friday, 9am – 5 pm

    In addition to these sites, there are College Access Centers located in 21 schools throughout the city. Trained professionals are available to help you with applications, financial aid applications and general college information. For a list of schools with a College Access Center click here.

    Computer Resources

    Computers are a necessary tool in the college application and financial aid process. If you need to use a computer for homework, college applications, or anything else, you can visit one of Philadelphia's new computer centers. These centers offer free computer and internet access, as well as free classes to help you brush up on your computer skills. Centers will be opening across the city over the summer and fall, if there is not yet a center near you check back in a couple months to see if new centers have opened.

    The Young People's Computer Center offers a community space and computer access for young people. Over the summer they will also be offering workshops on finding a summer job and getting ready for college at 1 PM every Thursday. The center is on the 2nd floor at 4205 Chestnut St and is open Monday-Thursday, 11 AM - 5 PM. For more info email chris@mediamobilizing.org or call 215-253-4586.

What tests you need to take to get into college and where to get help

Many colleges require you to submit scores from a college admissions test when you apply. There are two college admissions test, the SAT and the ACT. In Philadelphia, more students take the SAT than the ACT, but you may want to take both tests. They have a different format and some people get better scores on one or the other. The SAT tests math, reading, and writing and is broken down into many sections that are around twenty minutes long. The ACT tests math, reading, writing, and science and is broken down into four longer sections. Both tests are about four hours long.

In school in 11th grade you will take the PSAT, which is the practice test for the SAT. You should take the SAT or ACT for the first time in the spring of your junior year in high school. You can retake them again in your senior year of high school if your scores are not as good as you want them to be.

All of these tests cost money to take, but fee waivers are available through many high schools and sometimes through the testing companies. Talk to your school counselor for more information on fee waivers. You may also want to check the websites of the SAT and ACT for more information on fees and waivers.

You have to register for the SAT and ACT at least a month before taking the test.

Click here for information on registering for the SAT, or here for information on registering for the ACT.

The SAT and ACT are challenging, but there are a lot of resources that can help you prepare for them. The websites for both tests offer free online study tools, like practice questions. Many libraries carry copies of SAT and ACT prep books with detailed information, tips, and full length practice tests.

Many organizations in the city offer free SAT and ACT prep classes. You can search our calendar to find a class that works for you.

For low cost individualized help you can contact JEVS, they offer a sliding scale fee for classes and tutoring services.

How To Apply To The College Of Your Choice

Applying to college takes more than just filling out a form and mailing it in. Here is some information that can help you find your way.

  • The Five Things You Need to Know in Applying to Any College

    1. Some times, there is a fee you have to pay when filling out an application. However, these fees can often be waived for students with financial hardship. Call the admissions office of the college to find out if fees can be waived.
    2. Almost every college has a flashy brochure for its application. Don’t just be dazzled by cool pictures.
    3. If you really like the college, try to visit on-site first before submitting your application.
    4. Check out the college you like on-line thoroughly. It can give you a great snapshot.
    5. Be aware of application deadlines!

What Kind of College Fits You Best?

Finding the right college for you can take a little work. Fortunately, many great websites are available that allow you to plug in your interests, your SAT scores, your grades and a bunch of other things to get a list of schools that match who you are as a student.

Once you have your list of potential colleges, you should contact them to request information. Go to the link provided below to access individual schools. Remember to look at the college as a whole — big campus versus small campus, city versus urban, close to home versus far away, state school versus private institution — all of these factors should be a part of your decision where to apply.


  • To plug in what you like and find colleges that match your interests go to www.CollegeBoard.com or www.fastweb.com.

  • For information on local colleges in Philadelphia and as well as Philadelphia-specific information, go to www.campusphilly.org.

  • If you want to check out a list of all colleges and universities in the United States, click this link www.utexas.edu/world/univ/state.

  • Visiting a college is an important way to find out if it is the right fit for you. If you are unable to visit a college you might want to take a virtual tour. Check out the following sites for virtual tours: www.campustours.com , www.ecampustours.com

  • If you want to check out an Historically Black College or University (commonly known as an “HBCU”), click here. Pennsylvania has two HBCUs: Cheyney University and Lincoln University

  • If you are considering beginning your college experience at a community college make sure the classes you take will transfer to other colleges and universities. Find out what colleges accept credits from the community college you plan to attend.

  • To check out a calendar of college fairs www.nacacnet.org.

  • If you’re looking for a college to accommodate students with learning disabilities, visit Landmark College.

item.title: Help Your Student Develop a Budget for College
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Just about everybody gets some money to help them pay for college. But in order to find out how much your student might receive for college, you need to first determine what they’re eligible for. The first step is to complete the FAFSA form (which stands for the Free Application for Federal Student Aid) to find out how much money they are eligible to receive to go to college. If you go to fill out a FAFSA form, you’ll need:

  • Your Student’s Social Security Number or Alien Registration Number if they’re not a U.S. citizen
  • Their Driver’s License Number (if they have one)
  • W-2 forms from the last two years
  • Your 1040 Federal Tax Income Return (if you are a parent applying for your child, you’ll need yours, your spouse’s and your dependent child’s)
  • Records of Untaxed Income (i.e., TANF, Social Security, Welfare or Veterans Benefits)

There are organizations out there that can help you fill out these forms and let you know how much financial aid your student can get to go to college. The FAFSA Forecaster predicts what aid may be available to your student.

The Benefit Bank is a service available in the community that helps Philadelphians complete their taxes and apply for other services. People who use The Benefit Bank (TBB) to file their tax returns can use the TBB's auto-fill feature to automatically fill in the FAFSA form.

The Campaign for Working Families provides free tax completion assistance if your income meets certain guidelines. Some of their walk-in assistance sites will also help you complete the FAFSA.

If you need assistance completing the FAFSA, you may attend one of the free workshops happening all over the city as part of the City-Wide FAFSA Completion and Financial Aid Campaign. Check out our calendar to find a workshop near you.

You can also visit a Trusted Center during designated hours for assistance. Click here to download a list of Trusted Centers.

Tax Credits for College

The American Opportunity Tax Credit offers a rebate of up to $2,500 for college expenses. To qualify for this credit you must earn under $80,000 if you file as single, or under $160,000 if you file as married. The $2,500 credit can be claimed by parents for each child that is in college, or, if the student files their taxes as an independent, by students themselves. Click here to download a document with more details on how to file for this credit.

Philly Goes To College Scholarship Resources

Remember, for anybody going to college, there are dollars available from at least three sources (after you determine what you’re eligible for): money from the state where you live, money from the federal government and scholarships from the college where you want to go to school. Here are the Top 5 things you need to do before you apply for any scholarship:

  1. If you are applying for college scholarships and you also need financial aid, you must first complete the FAFSA application.
  2. Your local library has books and information on scholarship information and is a great resource. Check out free workshops sponsored by the library on college-going topics.
  3. Once you have been admitted to college, ask the financial aid specialists at that school if there are specific scholarships you may apply for. Don’t assume they will just tell you!
  4. Each year millions of dollars in scholarships go unassigned. Be careful to look at the criteria needed to apply such as age, race, religion, specific interest, etc. There just might be a scholarship right for you!
  5. Scholarship providers do not charge a fee for submitting an application or recommending a scholarship to which you want to apply. Beware of scams!

Top Websites for Scholarship Information

There are scholarships that are awarded based on a wide range of factors… how well you perform academically in college… how well you perform athletically (if you’re into sports)… or any number of characteristics. Below you can look through scholarships for Philadelphians, browse lists of scholarships, or use a scholarship search engine to find scholarships that match your interests and skills.

  • Scholarships for Philadelphia Residents

    CORE Philly offers last dollar scholarships to high school seniors of up to $2000 to cover unmet financial need for their first year of college. The only eligibility requirement is enrollment at Community College of Philadelphia or any Pennsylvania State-Related college or university. For a list of eligible institutions visit their website.

    The Philadelphia City Scholarship Program gives students $1,000/year to attend a college location in the greater Philadelphia area.

    Center for Student Opportunity allows students to create a profile to search for scholarships and receive relevant college information. Creating a profile also qualifies you to apply for a scholarship they offer.

    The Philadelphia Foundation manages several different scholarships intended for Philadelphia students. You can view the list of scholarships and download applications on their website.

    The Philadelphia Scholars Fund offers scholarships to Philadelphia high school students who have participated in College Access Programs at one of twenty one Philadelphia public high schools. Check their website to see if your school is eligible.

    The Urban League of Philadelphia offers several scholarships including the Community Scholarship Program and the American Association of Blacks in Energy/Urban League of Philadelphia Scholarship. Call for more information on scholarships, 215-985-3220, ext. 208.

    Scholarships to Local Colleges and Universities

    The Community College of Philadelphia offers the Robert S. King Scholarship to eligible students who graduate from a high school within the city of Philadelphia. For more information contact Patti Conroy at 215.751.8214 or pconroy@ccp.edu.

    Drexel Liberty Scholars provides full tuition scholarships to low-income students from Philadelphia and is renewable annually.

    The Philadelphia Scholars Award offered by Harrisburg University of Science and Technology provides a full tuition scholarship renewable over four years to students from Philadelphia.

    Peirce College offers the Mayor's Scholarship to one Philadelphia resident and one employee of the city of Philadelphia each year. It consists of a full tuition scholarship, renewable yearly. Submit the application, along with the essay and other materials described here to apply.

    Penn State Alumni Association Scholarship is available to current first year students from Philadelphia who attend any Penn State campus. Scholarships of $1,000 each will be awarded to two students. The completed application is due October 1st 2010.

    The Mayor’s Scholarship Program through the University of Pennsylvania fully meets financial need and is renewable over four years.

    Websites to Help You Find Scholarships

    The School District of Philadelphia sorts scholarships into lists by application deadline. This is a good place to start if you are feeling overwhelmed by search engines that list hundreds of scholarships. You do not have to attend a School District of Philadelphia school to use the site!

    CollegeBoard, Education Planner, and FastWeb all offer very detailed scholarship search engines that allow you to save a profile and enter information on everything from your grades to medical conditions. The engines use this information to find ideal scholarships for you.

    United Negro College Fund has a scholarship search engine, but also allows you to browse lists of scholarships with upcoming deadlines.

    ASPIRA provides a list of scholarships on their website.

    The Black Alliance for Educational Options (BAEO) offers a list of 200 scholarships on their website.

    Scholarships 4 Students lists scholarships based on categories. It has a list for high school students, a list for current college students, a list by college major, etc.

    Loans

    Student loans can be a last resort to make up the difference between what you can afford to pay and the financial assistance you have received from the government, your college and private scholarships. Taking out loans can be scary, but most students have to borrow at least a small amount of money to pay for college. There is a federal loan program just for students that offers low interest loans that you do not have to begin paying back until you are no longer in school. If you have to borrow, federal loans should be your first choice.

    There are two types of federal student loans, subsidized and unsubsidized. To find out which one you qualify for you will have to complete the FAFSA, information on the FAFSA is included at the top of this page. If your loan is subsidized, this means that the government will pay off the interest that is charged to your loan while you are in college. When you are out of college you will only be responsible for paying the exact amount that you borrowed. If your loan is unsubsidized you will be responsible for paying the interest that is charged to your loan, as well as the original amount you borrowed.

    Parents may also borrow money to help pay for their student's education through the federal Parent PLUS loan program. Like federal student loans, Parent PLUS loans offer lower interest rates than loans from a bank.

    Click here to view a chart showing different types of student and parent loan options.

    Loan Forgiveness

    If you plan to go into public service, such as teaching or working for the government, you may be eligible for the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program. This program offers loan forgiveness to individuals who have worked in public service positions for ten years while making payments on their loans. After ten years of payments, 120 payments, have been made the remainder of the loan will be forgiven. To count towards the 120, payments must have been made after October of 2007. Click here to download a document with details.

item.title: For Adult Students
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Did you know that — with a college degree — you are more likely to stay employed, buy houses, marry, pay taxes, avoid welfare, volunteer for socially useful causes, vote, be happier and healthier, and live longer? And over their lifetime, studies have shown that — on average — college graduates earn $2 million in wages (that’s more than $1 million more than high school graduates make).

Going to and graduating from college as an adult student is an investment in yourself that does pay off. If you’re pursuing your degree as an adult student, you can connect with a good number of resources through this website. Just remember these key things:

  • Determining What Your Budget Can Afford

    Going to college is an investment but there are many resources to help you afford it while balancing your other financial responsibilities. You can learn about the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), scholarships and loans on this page.

  • Develop a Plan

    Making a plan to get your degree is critical. Learn about special programs for adults returning to college, how you can get college credit for life experience and resources to prepare you for college.

item.title: Find Ways to Pay for College
item.dc:creator: admin

  • Records of Untaxed Income (i.e., TANF, Social Security, Welfare or Veterans Benefits)

The deadline for completing the FAFSA in order to qualify for PA state grants is May 1st for 4 year colleges, and August 1st for 2 year and trade colleges. Some colleges allocate aid on a first come first serve basis, so make sure to get your FAFSA completed as soon as possible.

item.title: Develop A Plan
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Going to college is a process. And it takes some work to help your student find the right path for them. Fortunately, there are some great web resources that can help you figure it all out.

  • Helping your student through high school graduation and on to college

    The Graduation Coaches Campaign empowers adults to help their students through high school graduation and beyond by providing resources and information. Visit their website to learn how to keep your student on the path to college.

    A Free Guide Showing You and Your Student The Way

    The Step Up To College Guide offers information on what courses your student needs to take in high school to apply to college, how to organize the college search, information on standardized tests and financial aid, as well as other useful topics. Click here and you can look through the guide on-line or print out a copy of your own.These free guides are also available in schools, libraries and community organizations.

    • Track Their Progress

    If your student attends a school operated by the School District of Philadelphia they can log on to StudentNet to view their grades, the classes they've taken, and their test scores. Click here to visit the site and learn how you can help them track their progress.

  • Information on making the most out of high school

    The Office of College and Career Awareness of the School District of Philadelphia provides resources to students, school staff, parents and the community to achieve academic and career success. Your student doesn’t even have to attend a Philadelphia public school to take advantage of this free resource. Click here to go to their website and get comprehensive information on high school classes needed to apply to college, college prep workshops, financial aid information, scholarship listings and more.

  • Helping Your Elementary or Middle School Student Prepare for College

    The sooner your student starts preparing for college the better!

    The classes they take in middle school can effect how prepared they are for college. Click here for information on what classes students should take to prepare for college.

    You can also help them prepare for college by planning for their high school experience. In Philadelphia students can attend a neighborhood high school, or apply to a different type of school. Click here for information on public high schools, and click here for information on charter and private high schools.

    For more information on choosing a high school check out the Philadelphia Public School Notebook's High School Guide.

  • Getting Practical Advice From Parents/Mentors Already Helping Students On Their Way

    KnowHow2Go is a campaign sponsored by the American Council on Education, the Lumina Foundation for Education and the Ad Council to help students in middle school through 12th grade prepare for college. Although the site is very student-friendly, there is some great information available by clicking the “Mentors” button.

  • Getting Expert Advice When Thinking, Choosing or Paying for College

    EducationPlanner.org is a comprehensive website sponsored by American Education Services (AES) which is a non-profit organization and is among the nation's leading providers of student financial aid services. Click here to find out how they can help you plan your student’s path to college.

    Computer Resources

    Computers are a necessary tool in the college application and financial aid process. If your student needs to use a computer for homework, college applications, or anything else, they can visit one of Philadelphia's new computer centers. These centers offer free computer and internet access, as well as free classes on computer skills. Centers will be opening across the city over the summer and fall, if there is not yet a center near you or your student check back in a couple months to see if new centers have opened.

    The Young People's Computer Center offers a community space and computer access for young people. Over the summer they will also be offering workshops for young people on finding a summer job and getting ready for college at 1 PM every Thursday. The center is on the 2nd floor at 4205 Chestnut St and is open Monday-Thursday, 11 AM - 5 PM. For more information email chris@mediamobilizing.org or call 215-253-4586.

What Tests Your Student Needs to Take to Get Into College And Where to Get Help

There are some tests your student needs to prepare for before applying to college. There is the ACT which is a national college admissions examination that consists of subject area tests in English, Math, Reading and Science. Then there’s the SAT which is also a national college admissions exam and the prep test (PSAT). There is usually no charge to take the PSAT which is often given to students before their senior year in high school, but when you take the ACT or SAT there is often a fee you have to pay to take it and the tests are only offered during certain times of the year. Check out their websites for more information.

Fortunately, there are a good number of programs that can help you prepare for these tests and some of prep classes are offered for free or low cost. Check them out on these websites:

  • College Board – SAT registration, scores, test prep
  • Free Library of Philadelphia – SAT prep classes at some local locations
  • The Princeton Review – Test prep, college information and other resources.
  • JEVS – Offers a sliding scale fee for classes/tutoring services
  • Kaplan – Charges a fee for prep classes/tutoring services

How to Match Your Student With the Best College Fit

  • To fill in information about your student and find colleges that match their interests and skills go to www.CollegeBoard.com or www.fastweb.com.

  • For information on local colleges in Philadelphia and as well as Philadelphia-specific information, go to www.campusphilly.org.

  • To view a list of all colleges and universities in the United States, click this link www.utexas.edu/world/univ/state.

  • Visiting a college is an important way to find out if it is the right fit for you. If your student is unable to visit a college they might want to take a virtual tour. They can check out the following sites for virtual tours: www.campustours.com , www.ecampustours.com

  • If your student wants to check out a Historically Black College or University (commonly known as an “HBCU”), click here. Pennsylvania has two HBCUs: Cheyney University and Lincoln University

  • If your student is considering beginning their college experience at a community college make sure the classes they take will transfer to other colleges and universities. Find out what colleges accept credits from the community college your student plans to attend.

  • To check out a calendar of college fairs here: www.nacacnet.org. College fairs are a great way to learn more about many different schools.

  • If you’re looking for a college to accommodate students with learning disabilities, visit Landmark College.

How to Help with the Student's College Application

  • The Five Things You Need to Know in Applying to Any College

    1. Some times, there is a fee you have to pay when filling out an application. However, these fees can often be waived for students with financial hardship. Call the admissions office of the college to find out if fees can be waived.
    2. Almost every college has a flashy brochure for its application. Don’t let your student be dazzled by a smart marketing pitch.
    3. If your student really likes the college, try to help them arrange an on-site visit first before submitting their application.
    4. Check out the college your student likes on-line thoroughly. It can give you a great snapshot.
    5. Be aware of application deadlines! Make sure your student stays on top of things.

Free Help With the College Application Process

If your student is in high school, the Philadelphia Education Fund has three College Access Centers open in three areas of the City to provide them with free help with the college application process, financial aid, scholarships and other things:

  • The Gallery I, Street Level – Center City
    9th and Market Streets
    Philadelphia, PA 19107
    215.574.1341
    Open Monday – Thursday, 10 am – 6 pm; Friday 10 am – 5 pm
  • The Enterprise Center – West Philadelphia
    4548 Market Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19139
    215.476.2227
    Open Monday – Friday, 9 am – 5 pm
  • Rivera Building – North Philadelphia
    2603 N. 5th Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19133
    215.739.9360
    Open Monday – Friday, 9am – 5 pm
In addition to these sites, there are College Access Centers located in 21 schools throughout the city. Trained professionals are available to help your student with applications, financial aid applications and general college information. For a list of schools with a College Access Center click here.

Student Success Centers Information

Student Success Centers are another free option for high school students. They can help your student create a plan for getting into college, and also provide counseling services to help them make it through high school. To see if your student's school has a Student Success Center click here.

item.title: Keep Your Student Motivated and Moving
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The only person who can make college a reality is your student – with a little bit of help from you, of course. Even though you can help them, your student is ultimately responsible for the college experience he or she makes.

  • Using “StudentNet” to Keep You On Track to College

    Part of the journey for going to college is having your student take responsibility for their own academic performance. Every Philadelphia public school student has access to StudentNet, an online portal that allows them to view their own academic record.

    On StudentNet, your student can view their academic records… including report cards, credit accumulation, current attendance record and scores on all benchmark and standardized assessments to let them (and you) know where they stand.

  • Building Success Outside the Classroom

    There are many programs available after school and outside the classroom that can help your student prepare for college as well as build experiences that help make them an attractive candidate to get into college. Browse the programs below to find one that fits your student.

    Students can also use Khan Academy to practice skills in algebra, history and more, for free! The site offers free lessons and quizes on many different subjects that allow students to learn at their own pace.

Summer Programs


Summer programs are a great way to stay on track for college! There are many summer opportunities around the city that offer the chance to earn money, learn something new, or participate in arts and cultural activities. Click here for more information on summer programs.

Student Mentorship and Enrichment Programs

  • ASAP
    After School Activities Partnerships
    They can plug you into a range of after school clubs in all schools in the city.
    215.545.2727
    1520 Locust Street, Suite 1104
    Philadelphia, PA 19102
  • ASPIRA PA
    Empowers the community through advocacy and education and leadership development for youth. Programs offer: career readiness, talent search, and leadership development.
    Click here for a list of schools with ASPIRA programs.
    215.455.1300
    info@aspirapa.org
    4322 North 5th Street, 3rd Floor
    Philadelphia, PA 19140
  • Boys and Girls Clubs
    Clubs located in many neighborhoods and offer leadership development, career and college planning, volunteering opportunities to high school students.
    215.735.8818
    reception@bgcphila.org
    1518 Walnut Street, Suite 712
    Philadelphia, PA 19102
  • Concerned Black Men, Inc. (Philadelphia Chapter)
    Services to boys and girls including mentoring, SAT prep, links to scholarships and tours of Historically Black Colleges and Universities.
    7200 N. 21st Street
    Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19138
    215.276.2260
  • Congreso de Latinos Unidos
     Services include after-school and evening programs for high school students that focus on leadership development, community service, academic enrichment, and college and career readiness. Congreso also partners with Harcum College to offer college courses in communities.
    215.763.8870
    216 West Somerset Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19133
  • Franklin Institute
    PACTS (Partnership for Achieving Careers in Technology and Science) is a year round after school youth leadership program with an emphasis on science and technology. Mentoring, career development and leadership skills are also provided. Summer programs are also available. Middle and high school students must apply to this program to participate.
  • Free Library of Philadelphia
    The Free Library provides free SAT and ACT prep classes and other college prep workshops throughout the year. They also have books and other resources on colleges, SAT prep, scholarship information, and more. Visit their website to find a branch near you. You may also visit the Parkway Central Library located at 19th & Vine Streets.
  • Police Athletic League (PAL)
    Groups keep boys and girls active, interested and busy. They provide supervised recreational and education programs to develop leadership skills and build good citizens. They offer sports, leadership and educational programs at their centers around Philadelphia.
    215.291.9000
    2524 E. Clearfield Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19134
  • Philadelphia Center for Arts and Technology
    Classes are available to students ages 14-24 on topics that bring together technology and the arts. The classes teach career skills and also provide students with leadership development and mentorship. Students must apply to this program to participate.
    2111-31 Eastburn Avenue
    Philadelphia, PA 19138
    267-297-6231
  • Philadelphia Youth Network (PYN) E3 Centers
    Five centers are designed to provide education, employment and empowerment resources for out of school and disconnected youth between the ages 14 – 24.Click here for locations and contact information.
  • Summer Search
     Leadership Development Program that offers weekly mentoring, college prep assistance and offers summer enrichment programs and trips. Students must apply to this program to participate.
    215.399.4906
    1616 Walnut Street, Suite 2200
    Philadelphia, PA 19103
  • Urban League of Philadelphia
     Offers leadership development opportunities, financial workshops and scholarships for African-American youth. Students must apply to this program to participate.
    215.985.3220
    121 S. Broad Street, 9th Floor
    Philadelphia, PA 19107
  • YMCA Achievers Program
     Provides career mentoring and academic enrichment for teens in 7th – 12 grade.
    215-235-6550
    Columbia North YMCA
    1400 North Broad Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19121
  • WorkReady
     Offers paid internships and summer jobs for high school students, as well as career mentoring programs and job shadowing opportunities. Students must apply to this program to participate.
    267-502-3742
    714 Market St., Suite 304
    Philadelphia, PA 19106

item.title: Develop A Plan
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
With all the demands on your life, pursuing your college degree requires a plan that is realistic, practical and achievable. Here are some resources to help you craft yours.

  • Graduate! Philadelphia

    If you’re an adult who already has some college credit and want to complete your degree, you can connect with Graduate! Philadelphia.

    They provide free guidance and supports to get you back to college and until you graduate.

    Their main office is located at The Gallery I, Street Level – Center City, 9th and Market Streets, Philadelphia, PA 19107, Phone: 215-574-1341.
    Open Monday, Thursday, Friday 10 am – 5 pm; Tuesday and Friday 10 am – 7 pm
    Walk-ins are welcome: Monday, Friday 10 am – 2 pm; Tuesday, Wednesday 3 pm – 7 pm

  • Educational Opportunity Center

    If you’re a student that is 19 years of age and older and you want to go to college or have some college credit and want to complete your degree, you can connect to the Education Opportunity Center:

    Educational Opportunity Center – Penn State University.

    Educational Opportunity Center – University of Pennsylvania – For West Philadelphia students only.

    A Resource Just for Veterans

    If you are veteran, there is a program called Veterans Upward Bound that can help you prepare for college academically, and offer ongoing support as you work towards your degree. They can be reached at 215.898.6892. Connect with them to see if you’re eligible.

    College-Level Examination Program

    If you are interested in receiving college credit for life and work experience, you can go to www.collegeboard.com and look into CLEP (the College-Level Examination Program). There is a fee charge for each exam you opt to take.

    Returning to Learning Partnership

    When choosing a college, City of Philadelphia employees may want to consider colleges that are a member of the Returning to Learning Partnership. This program offers city employees a 25% tuition discount at the following partner institutions: Chestnut Hill College, Community College of Philadelphia, Peirce College, Philadelphia University, Rosemont College, Neumann University, and Widener University. Please check the PhillyGoes2College calendar for dates and locations of upcoming information sessions. Click here to download an employee discount fact sheet.

    GED and Diploma completion resources

  • Mayor’s Commission on Literacy

    If you’re a student who would like attend college but first need to earn your GED (General Educational Development), you can contact the Mayor’s Commission on Literacy at 215-686-5250 to get information on GED programs.

  • Philadelphia School District Re-Engagement Center

    The School District operates a Re-Engagement Center that offers help for students ages 16 - 21 who need help getting a high school diploma or their GED.

    You can visit them on the first floor of the School District building at 440 N. Broad Street
    Monday through Friday 7:30 AM – 6 PM or you can call them 215.400.6700 or drop them an e-mail at reengagementcenter@philasd.org

    The Free Library of Philadelphia's Reader Development Program

    This program offers adult learners free literacy,GED, pre-GED, and ESL books. If you are studying for your GED or working to improve your literacy skills call 215-686-5346, Monday-Friday, 9am-5pm, to find out how to take advantage of this resource.

    Practice on your own

    Khan Academy offers free online lessons and practice on many topics including math, reading and science. This is a great tool for practicing skills, and a fun way to learn about new subjects.

    Computer Resources

    Computers are a necessary tool in the college application and financial aid process. If you need to use a computer for homework, college applications, or anything else, you can visit one of Philadelphia's new computer centers. These centers offer free computer and internet access, as well as free classes on computer skills. Centers will be opening across the city over the summer and fall, if there is not yet a center near you check back in a couple months to see if new centers have opened.

    • What Kind of College Fits You Best?

    Finding the right college for you can take a little work. Fortunately, many great websites are available that allow you to plug in your interests and a bunch of other things to get a list of schools that match who you are as a student.

    • To plug in what you like and find colleges that match your interests go to www.CollegeBoard.com or www.fastweb.com.

    • For information on local colleges in Philadelphia and as well as Philadelphia-specific information, go to www.campusphilly.org.

    • If you want to check out a list of all colleges and universities in the United States, click this link www.utexas.edu/world/univ/state.

    • For information on touring colleges and universities visit www.campustours.com.

    • If you want to check out an Historically Black College or University (commonly known as an “HBCU”), click here. Pennsylvania has two HBCUs: Cheyney University and Lincoln University

    • To check out a calendar of college fairs www.nacacnet.org.

    • If you’re looking for a college to accommodate students with learning disabilities, visit Landmark College.

      • Community College of Philadelphia

      Community College of Philadelphia is the largest institution of public education in Philadelphia. CCP offers over 70 different degree and certificate programs. CCP has strong ties to local colleges and universities for those students who want to continue their education and earn a 4-year degree. Class schedules are flexible and are held in four different locations throughout the city. In addition, online classes are available. Over 53% of the students enrolled are over the age of 25, most having entered college for the first time. Substantial supports are in place to help adults start on their path to college degree attainment.

      If you are considering beginning your college experience at a community college make sure the classes you take will transfer to other colleges and universities. Find out what colleges accept credits from the community college you plan to attend.

item.title: For Students
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you’re a student looking to go to college, just remember these key things:

  • Plan Your Pathway

    You can use these online tools to access general information on applying for college, on finding the right school for you and on the standardized tests you will need to take to apply for college.

  • Connect to a caring adult

    Find out about organizations and programs that want you to go to college, and will connect you with people and resources that can help.

  • Find Ways to Pay for College

    On this page you can find out about the many resources available to help you complete the FAFSA, and find grants, loans and scholarships.

  • Make It Happen

    Going to college is something you have to make happen, be responsible for you. You can find resources here that will help you keep track of your academic progress, and academic programs that will help you prepare for college.

item.title: test pop down options
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Preparing for College
Preparing for college starts as early as middle school. Middle school grades determine what high school you will be able to attend, and some high schools better prepare you for college then others...click to continue

If you are a student in a School District of Philadelphia school you can take responsibility for your academic progress by using StudentNet to keep track of your grades and test scores.

The Step Up To College guide has information on everything you need to know about planning for college from now until your senior year.

For information on what you can do in middle school to get ready for college visit: www.knowhow2go.com

The Right High School
The high school application process in Philadelphia can be confusing. Check out the following websites to learn about the different types of high schools ....click here to continue reading

...in the city and how the high school selection process works.

The Philadelphia Public School Notebook’s high school guide ( http://www.thenotebook.org/fall-guide-2009/091653/applying-district-high-schools-timeline-8th-grade-students ) The School District of Philadelphia (http://www.phila.k12.pa.us/students/voluntarytransfers.html)

Plan Your Pathway You can use these online tools to access general information on applying for college, on finding the right school for you and on the standardized tests you will need to take to apply for college.
Connect to a caring adult Find out about organizations and programs that want you to go to college, and will connect you with people and resources that can help.
Find Ways to Pay for College On this page you can find out about the many resources available to help you complete the FAFSA, and find grants, loans and scholarships.
Make It Happen Going to college is something you have to make happen, be responsible for you. You can find resources here that will help you keep track of your academic progress, and academic programs that will help you prepare for college.
Check out free upcoming events that will help you prepare for college and find financial aid!

item.title: Adult Students
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Did you know that — with a college degree — you are more likely to stay employed, buy houses, marry, pay taxes, avoid welfare, volunteer for socially useful causes, vote, be happier and healthier, and live longer? And over their lifetime, studies have shown that — on average — college graduates earn $2 million in wages (that’s more than $1 million more than high school graduates make). Going to and graduating from college as an adult student is an investment in yourself that does pay off. If you’re pursuing your degree as an adult student, you can connect with a good number of resources through this website. Just remember these key things:

item.content:encoded:
IntroductionThe Mayor’s Office of Education (the “MOE”) is committed to providing residents and visitors interested in pursuing higher education with valuable information regarding a variety of educational opportunities. Through this website, www.phillygoes2college.com (the “Website”), MOE is providing information, tools, and links to other websites (collectively “Educational Resources”) with the goal of increasing enrollment of Philadelphia residents into institutions of higher education. In order to best tailor MOE’s services, including the Website, to your needs and preferences, the Website may at times collect, store, and manage information entered by you into the Website, as well as automatically collected information related to your use of the Website, as described below (collectively the “Information”). MOE respects right to privacy and has prepared this privacy policy to inform you of the Information MOE collects and how MOE may use and disclose the Information.
Collection of InformationMOE collects general Internet based Information for statistical purposes from anyone visiting the Website. Your browser type, Internet domain (www.yourcompany.com), time and date of visit, pages viewed, third party website links accessed and IP address (unique computer identifier) are examples of the type of such Information collected. This Information is collected automatically, without your interaction. It is used to improve this Website and better serve our users.
In addition to Information collected automatically, you have the opportunity to enter Information which will assist MOE in providing Educational Resources to you. Such Information includes, but is not necessarily limited to: name, age, gender, year in school, education level, educational background, relationship to current and/or prospective students, email address and geographical information such as where you reside. Except as provided in this Privacy Statement, MOE will not disclose Information that you provide through the Website to third parties.
Use and Disclosure of InformationMOE may use and disclose Information collected from and about you for the following purposes: (1) to enhance, tailor, and customize services offered on the Website; (2) to contact you directly to provide you with Educational Resources; (3) to review your use of the Website; (4) to inform organizations that provide educational services about prospective students which may result in you being contacted by such third party; (5) to compile statistical data; 6) to help establish a direct line of communication between you and colleges, universities and other institutions of higher learning; and, 7) to assist the School District of Philadelphia and other high schools attended by residents of the City of Philadelphia in providing you with resources related to your interest in pursuing post-secondary and higher education MOE may at times share your Information with third party organizations including, but not limited to: (1) organizations under contract to act on behalf of MOE; (2) colleges, universities and other institutions of higher learning that provide post-secondary and higher education; (3) the School District of Philadelphia and other schools attended by residents of the City of Philadelphia. Information may also be shared as required by law including, but not limited to, all applicable federal, state and local government information laws, and the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act as codified at 65 P.S. § 65.101. CookiesCookies are small data files that are transferred by a web application to the user’s hard drive. These files are used to store information related to the user, such as, ID, passwords etcetera. This information is provided by the user via interaction with a web application or site. Cookies do not access information on the user’s computer. Their primary purpose is to make the users experience more enjoyable on there next visit to the site. Cookie management is controlled at the browser level. The user can turn off cookie transfer via the configuration option of their browser. The applications on the Website may at times transfer cookies to the user’s hard drive. MOE is committed to using cookie technology responsibly and will make every effort to protect the user’s computer environment from highly unlikely cookie related damage. SecurityMOE is committed to maintaining the security and integrity of personally identifiable information and other Information that is either available from or collected by the Website, and has taken reasonable precautions to protect Information from loss, misuse, alteration, or unauthorized disclosure or use. Unless a particular page on the Website states clearly that encryption technology is being used, the City cannot and does not ensure the security or confidentiality of Information uploaded through that page. The City will take reasonable precautions to safeguard the confidentiality of Information, but shall not be liable for any injury or damages arising from the disclosure of Information, whether caused by security breach or by any act or omission of the City. AgreementBy accessing and using the Website you consent to MOE’s collection, use and disclosure of Information as described in this Privacy Statement.

item.title: For Parents/Mentors
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Did you know that college graduates are more likely to stay employed, buy houses, marry, pay taxes, avoid welfare, commit fewer crimes, volunteer for socially useful causes, vote, be happier and healthier, and live longer? And over their lifetime, studies have shown that — on average — college graduates earn $2 million in wages (that’s more than $1 million more than high school graduates make). Helping students go to and graduate from college is an investment that does pay off. If you’re a Parent/Mentor looking to help a student go to college, the pages below will help you connect with the resource you need.

  • Help Your Student Develop a Budget for College

    Going to college is an investment but there are many resources to help you pay for it. Find information on the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA), scholarships and loans.

  • Develop a Plan

    Helping your student get to and through college requires a plan. Learn how to prepare your student for college, how to help your student choose a college, and how to prepare your student for college admissions tests.

  • Keep Your Student Motivated and Moving

    Your student should work hard to prepare for college, but they also need help. Learn about academic enrichment programs that can help them prepare, and resources that help them keep track of their academic performance.

item.title: Determine What Your Budget Can Afford
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
What Can My Budget Afford?

Determine What Your Budget Can Afford

Just about everybody gets some money to help them pay for college. But in order to find out how much you can get for college, you need to first determine what you’re eligible to receive. The first step is to complete the FAFSA form (which stands for the Free Application for Federal Student Aid) to find out how much money you are eligible to receive to go to college. If you go to fill out a FAFSA form, you’ll need:

  • Your Social Security Number or Alien Registration Number if you’re not a U.S.citizen
  • Your Driver’s License Number (if you have one)
  • W-2 forms from the last two years
  • Your 1040 Federal Tax Income Return (as well as your parents’ tax return if you are a dependent child)
  • Records of Untaxed Income (i.e., TANF, Social Security, Welfare or Veterans Benefits)

There are organizations out there that can help you fill out these forms and let you know how much financial aid you can get to go to college. The FAFSA Forecaster

The Benefit Bank is a service available in the community that helps Philadelphians complete their taxes and apply for other services. People who use The Benefit Bank (TBB) to file their tax returns can use the TBB's auto-fill feature to automatically fill in the FAFSA form.

The Campaign for Working Families provides free tax completion assistance if your income meets certain guidelines. Some of their walk-in assistance sites will also help you complete the FAFSA.

If you need assistance completing the FAFSA, you may attend one of the free workshops happening all over the city as part of the City-Wide FAFSA Completion and Financial Aid Campaign. Check out our calendar to find a workshop near you.

You can also visit a Trusted Center during designated hours for assistance. Click here to download a list of Trusted Centers.

Tax Credits for College

The American Opportunity Tax Credit offers a rebate of up to $2,500 for college expenses. To qualify for this credit you must earn under $80,000 if you file as single, or under $160,000 if you file as married. The $2,500 credit can be claimed by parents for each child that is in college, or, if the student files their taxes as an independent, by students themselves. Click here to download a document with more details on how to file for this credit.

Philly Goes To College Scholarship Resources

Remember, for anybody going to college – no matter what age – there are dollars available from at least three sources (after you determine what you’re eligible for): money from the state where you live, money from the federal government and scholarships from the college where you want to go to school. Here are the Top 5 things you need to do before you apply for any scholarship:

  1. If you are applying for college scholarships and you also need financial aid, you must first complete the FAFSA application.
  2. Your local library has books and information on scholarship information and is a great resource. Check out free workshops sponsored by the library on college-going topics.
  3. Once you have been admitted to college, ask the financial aid specialists at that school if there are specific scholarships you may apply for. Don’t assume they will just tell you!
  4. Each year millions of dollars in scholarships go unassigned. Be careful to look at the criteria needed to apply such as age, race, religion, specific interest, etc. There just might be a scholarship right for you!
  5. Scholarship providers do not charge a fee for submitting an application or recommending a scholarship to which you want to apply. Beware of scams!

  • A Resource Just For The Adult Student

    Graduate! Philadelphia is a joint initiative of the Philadelphia Workforce Investment Board and the United Way of Southeastern Pennsylvania and 18 local colleges whose sole mission is to increase the number of adults with college degrees in the Greater Philadelphia region. They have tuition assistance information specifically for returning adult students that you can access by clicking here.

  • Programs for City of Philadelphia Employees

    The Mayor’s Returning to Learning Partnership is announcing a 25% tuition discount program for City of Philadelphia employees in partnership with the following colleges: Chestnut Hill College, Community College of Philadelphia, Peirce College, Philadelphia University and Rosemont College. Please check the PhillyGoes2College calendar for dates and locations of upcoming information sessions. Click here to download an employee discount fact sheet.

    Scholarships for Philadelphia Residents

    The Philadelphia Foundation manages several different scholarships intended for Philadelphia students. You can view the list of scholarships and download applications on their website.

    The Urban League of Philadelphia offers several scholarships including the Community Scholarship Program and the American Association of Blacks in Energy/Urban League of Philadelphia Scholarship. Call for more information on scholarships, 215-985-3220, ext. 208.

    Scholarships to Local Colleges and Universities

    The Community College of Philadelphia offers the Robert S. King Scholarship to eligible students who graduate from a high school within the city of Philadelphia. For more information contact Patti Conroy at 215.751.8214 or pconroy@ccp.edu.

    The Philadelphia Scholars Award offered by Harrisburg University of Science and Technology provides a full tuition scholarship renewable over four years to students from Philadelphia.

    Peirce College offers the Mayor's Scholarship to one Philadelphia resident and one employee of the city of Philadelphia each year. It consists of a full tuition scholarship, renewable yearly. Submit the application, along with the essay and other materials described here to apply.

    Websites to Help You Find Scholarships

    CollegeBoard, Education Planner, and FastWeb all offer very detailed scholarship search engines that allow you to save a profile and enter information on everything from your grades to medical conditions. The engines use this information to find ideal scholarships for you.

    United Negro College Fund has a scholarship search engine, but also allows you to browse lists of scholarships with upcoming deadlines.

    ASPIRA provides a list of scholarships on their website.

    The Black Alliance for Educational Options (BAEO) offers a list of 200 scholarships on their website.

    Scholarships 4 Students lists scholarships based on categories. It has a list for high school students, a list for current college students, a list by college major, etc.

    Loans

    Student loans can be a last resort to make up the difference between what you can afford to pay and the financial assistance you have received from the government, your college and private scholarships. Taking out loans can be scary, but most students have to borrow at least a small amount of money to pay for college. There is a federal loan program just for students that offers low interest loans that you do not have to begin paying back until you are no longer in school. If you have to borrow, federal loans should be your first choice.

    There are two types of federal student loans, subsidized and unsubsidized. To find out which one you qualify for you will have to complete the FAFSA, information on the FAFSA is included at the top of this page. If your loan is subsidized, this means that the government will pay off the interest that is charged to your loan while you are in college. When you are out of college you will only be responsible for paying the exact amount that you borrowed. If your loan is unsubsidized you will be responsible for paying the interest that is charged to your loan, as well as the original amount you borrowed.

    Parents may also borrow money to help pay for their student's education through the federal Parent PLUS loan program. Like federal student loans, Parent PLUS loans offer lower interest rates than loans from a bank.

    Click here to view a chart showing different types of student and parent loan options.

    Loan Forgiveness

    If you plan to go into public service, such as teaching or working for the government, you may be eligible for the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program. This program offers loan forgiveness to individuals who have worked in public service positions for ten years while making payments on their loans. After ten years of payments, 120 payments, have been made the remainder of the loan will be forgiven. To count towards the 120, payments must have been made after October of 2007. Click here to download a document with details.

item.title: Make It Happen
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The only person who can make college a reality is you. Even though you’ll get help, you are ultimately responsible for the college experience you make. But even before that, stay on top of your game so you can graduate from high school and go beyond.

  • Using “StudentNet” to Keep You On Track to College

    Part of the journey for going to college is taking responsibility for your academic performance. Every Philadelphia public high school student has access to "StudentNet” which is an online portal for you to view your own academic record and to access high quality resources for planning your path to graduation and beyond.

    On StudentNet, you can view your academic records… including your report cards, credit accumulation (total and by graduation area), your current attendance record and scores on all benchmark and standardized assessments to let you know where you stand in getting to college.

  • Get advice from other students

    Visit KnowHow2Go's website to hear students talk about choosing a college, financial aid, life as a college student, and more.

  • Take charge of your academic success

    The Free Library of Philadelphia has an online academic prep center, The Learning Express Library, that can help you build on your academic strengths and work to improve in subjects you find difficult. It offers SAT and ACT preparation and resources to help you improve your math, science, reading, writing, and study skills. To access the site all you need is a library card and your library card pin number. You can request a library card online, or visit your local branch to get one.

    Catch up on subjects you struggle with and advance in others! Khan Academy offers free online lessons and practice on many different subjects including algebra, history and biology.

    Programs for Students Who Will Begin College This September

    Community College of Philadelphia Center for Male Engagement Summer Enrichment Program
     Is targeted to African-American men who will graduate from high school in June 2010 and plan to enroll full time in CCP this fall. The program offers early orientation to CCP, academic and personal enrichment, mentoring and, upon successful completion, a $500 stipend. Students must apply to this program to participate; applications must be received by Thursday, May 27th. Contact the Center for Male Engagement at 215-751-8817 or cme@ccp.edu for more information.

    College Preparatory Academic Programs

    These college prep programs can provide guidance and academic support that will help you make it to college.

    • A Better Chance (ABC)
       Recruits, identifies and develops leaders among young people of color. Refers students in grades 6 – 11 to public and independent schools for placement and financial aid. Students receive access to educational and leadership opportunities. You must apply to this program to participate.
      215.753.9429
      P.O. Box 171
      Wyncote, PA 19095
    • Breakthrough of Greater Philadelphia
       This program is available to low income students in sixth grade through high school. Intensive summer and year round academic programs, mentoring and college prep programs designed to prepare students for college. Students must apply to this program to participate.
      215.-951-2398
      34 W Coulter Street
      Philadelphia, PA 19144
    • Educational Advancement Alliance
       After-school and Saturday programs focused on academic enrichment and college preparation. They also offer social opportunities such as college visits and peer support groups. You must apply to this program to participate.
      215.472.2500
      4548 Market Street, Suite LL04
      Philadelphia, PA 19139
    • Ellis Trust
       Grants are provided to girls in grades 9 – 12 from single parent families in need of aid to complete their high school education. Grant money can be used for tuition, tutoring, college visits, college application and entrance test fees, college courses, summer programs, visual and performing arts lessons, etc. You must apply to this program to participate.
      215.735.4483
      215 South Broad Street, 10th Floor
      Philadelphia, PA 19107
    • GEAR UP (Gain Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs)
       This state wide program run through the School District of Philadelphia work with sixth and seventh grade students and provide support until their high school graduation. They provide academic, mentoring and college guidance services. For a list of participating schools click here.
      School District of Philadelphia
      Gear Up Program
      440 North Broad Street
      Philadelphia PA, 19130
      215.400.4130
    • Philadelphia Futures
       Prepares students from low-income families who attend Philadelphia’s neighborhood schools to enter and succeed in college. They provide mentoring, academic enrichment, college guidance and financial incentives starting in 9th grade through the end of college. You must apply to this program to participate.
      215.790.1665
      230 South Broad Street, 7th Floor
      Philadelphia, PA 19102
    • Upward Bound
       Programs are designed to prepare students for four-year colleges and are offered to low-income students who are the first generation of their family to attend college. Programs are run through different colleges and universities in the city. Some programs are open to any low-income individual, while others serve only specific high schools or communities. You must apply to this program to participate.
    • Community College of Philadelphia Upward Bound – 215.751.8780 – Prepares high school students for college. Call to determine elegibility.
    • Lincoln University Upward Bound – 484.365.8000 – Offers tutoring and advising sessions, test preparation, and a six week residential summer program.
    • Penn State University Math and Science Upward Bound – 814.863.1296 – Offers a six week summer program focusing on math and science as well as year round academic programs. Eligible students from any Philadelphia area high school may apply.
    • Temple University Math and Science Upward Bound – 215.204.3636 – For students interested in math and science. Offers programs during and the school year and over the summer as well as academic support and counseling. Open to any Philadelphia public high school student.
    • University of Pennsylvania High School Upwards Bound – 215.898.3185 – Year-round program beginning in the fall run by the University of Pennsylvania. Only open to students from specific Philadelphia public high schools. Call, or check website to determine eligibility.
    • White-Williams Scholars
       Awards monthly stipends to high-achieving, low-income Philadelphia high school students who maintain good grades. Also provides college counseling, college trips and peer support groups. You must apply to this program to participate.
      215.735.4480
      215 South Broad Street, 10th Floor
      Philadelphia, PA 19107
