item.title: Connect to a Caring Adult
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Some times, the best way to take a journey into unfamiliar territory is connecting with someone who knows the terrain and can help guide each footstep. That caring adult could be your mother or father, or older relative or friend. There are also free places you can go where caring adults are ready, willing and able to help you.

For students in the School District of Philadelphia only, please click here if you would like us to provide your name and email to your high school guidance counselor for follow up with college-going supports.

College Access Centers

The Philadelphia Education Fund runs three College Access Centers located in three areas of the City to provide students of all ages with free help with the college application process, financial aid, scholarships and other things. All students are welcome at these sites:

  • The Gallery I, Street Level – Center City
    9th and Market Streets
    Philadelphia, PA 19107
    215.574.1341
    Open Monday – Thursday, 10 am – 6 pm; Friday 10 am – 5 pm
  • The Enterprise Center – West Philadelphia
    4548 Market Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19139
    215.476.2227
    Open Monday – Friday, 9 am – 5 pm
  • Rivera Building – North Philadelphia
    2603 N. 5th Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19133
    215.739.9360
    Open Monday – Friday, 9am – 5 pm
In addition to these sites, there are College Access Centers located in 21 schools throughout the city. Trained professionals are available to help you with applications, financial aid applications and general college information. For a list of schools with a College Access Center click here.

Student Success Centers Information

Student Success Centers are another free option for high school students. They can help you create a plan for getting into college, and also provide counseling services to help you make it through high school. To see if your school has a Student Success Center click here.

Summer Programs


Summer programs are a great way to stay on track for college! There are many summer opportunities around the city that offer the chance to earn money, learn something new, or participate in arts and cultural activities.

Click here for more information on summer programs for students of all ages.

You can also check out this guide to summer programs on local college campuses. These types of programs are a fun way to prepare for college and get a feel for what it is like to be on a campus.

Summer Mentorship Program at Penn This program offers 10th and 11th graders who attend a Philadelphia public or charter school the opportunity to spend four weeks at the University of Pennsylvania learning about dental medicine, engineering, law, medicine, or nursing. Students will earn a stipend after completing the program. Applications are due April 15th. Call 215-746-8242 for more information.

Penn Summer Academies These intensive four week long classes are offered to high school students. Three subject areas are available: biomedical reseach, experimental physics, and English for non-native speakers. Scholarships are available.

  • ASAP
    After School Activities Partnerships
    They can plug you into a range of after school clubs in all schools in the city.
    215.545.2727
    1520 Locust Street, Suite 1104
    Philadelphia, PA 19102
  • ASPIRA PA
    Empowers the community through advocacy and education and leadership development for youth. Programs offer: career readiness, talent search, and leadership development.
    Click here for a list of schools with ASPIRA programs.
    215.455.1300
    info@aspirapa.org
    4322 North 5th Street, 3rd Floor
    Philadelphia, PA 19140
  • Boys and Girls Clubs
    Clubs located in many neighborhoods and offer leadership development, career and college planning, volunteering opportunities to high school students.
    215.735.8818
    reception@bgcphila.org
    1518 Walnut Street, Suite 712
    Philadelphia, PA 19102
  • Concerned Black Men, Inc. (Philadelphia Chapter)
    Services to boys and girls including mentoring, SAT prep, links to scholarships and tours of Historically Black Colleges and Universities.
    7200 N. 21st Street
    Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19138
    215.276.2260
  • Congreso de Latinos Unidos
     Services include after-school and evening programs for high school students that focus on leadership development, community service, academic enrichment, and college and career readiness. Congreso also partners with Harcum College to offer college courses in communities.
    215.763.8870
    216 West Somerset Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19133
  • Franklin Institute
    PACTS (Partnership for Achieving Careers in Technology and Science) is a year round after school youth leadership program with an emphasis on science and technology. Mentoring, career development and leadership skills are also provided. Summer programs are also available. Middle and high school students must apply to this program to participate.
  • Free Library of Philadelphia
    The Free Library provides free SAT and ACT prep classes and other college prep workshops throughout the year. They also have books and other resources on colleges, SAT prep, scholarship information, and more. Visit their website to find a branch near you. You may also visit the Parkway Central Library located at 19th & Vine Streets.
  • Police Athletic League (PAL)
    Groups keep boys and girls active, interested and busy. They provide supervised recreational and education programs to develop leadership skills and build good citizens. They offer sports, leadership and educational programs at their centers around Philadelphia.
    215.291.9000
    2524 E. Clearfield Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19134
  • Philadelphia Center for Arts and Technology
    Classes are available to students ages 14-24 on topics that bring together technology and the arts. The classes teach career skills and also provide students with leadership development and mentorship. Students must apply to this program to participate.
    2111-31 Eastburn Avenue
    Philadelphia, PA 19138
    267-297-6231
  • Philadelphia Youth Network (PYN) E3 Centers
    Five centers are designed to provide education, employment and empowerment resources for out of school and disconnected youth between the ages 14 – 24.Click here for locations and contact information.
  • Summer Search
     Leadership Development Program that offers weekly mentoring, college prep assistance and offers summer enrichment programs and trips. Students must apply to this program to participate.
    215.399.4906
    1616 Walnut Street, Suite 2200
    Philadelphia, PA 19103
  • Urban League of Philadelphia
     Offers leadership development opportunities, financial workshops and scholarships for African-American youth. Students must apply to this program to participate.
    215.985.3220
    121 S. Broad Street, 9th Floor
    Philadelphia, PA 19107
  • YMCA Achievers Program
     Provides career mentoring and academic enrichment for teens in 7th – 12 grade.
    215-235-6550
    Columbia North YMCA
    1400 North Broad Street
    Philadelphia, PA 19121
  • WorkReady
     Offers paid internships and summer jobs for high school students, as well as career mentoring programs and job shadowing opportunities. Students must apply to this program to participate.
    267-502-3742
    714 Market St., Suite 304
    Philadelphia, PA 19106

item.title: Privacy Statement
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Introduction
The Mayor’s Office of Education (the “MOE”) is committed to providing residents and visitors interested in pursuing higher education with valuable information regarding a variety of educational opportunities. Through this website, www.phillygoes2college.com (the “Website”), MOE is providing information, tools, and links to other websites (collectively “Educational Resources”) with the goal of increasing enrollment of Philadelphia residents into institutions of higher education. In order to best tailor MOE’s services, including the Website, to your needs and preferences, the Website may at times collect, store, and manage information entered by you into the Website, as well as automatically collected information related to your use of the Website, as described below (collectively the “Information”). MOE respects right to privacy and has prepared this privacy policy to inform you of the Information MOE collects and how MOE may use and disclose the Information.

Collection of Information
MOE collects general Internet based Information for statistical purposes from anyone visiting the Website. Your browser type, Internet domain (www.yourcompany.com), time and date of visit, pages viewed, third party website links accessed and IP address (unique computer identifier) are examples of the type of such Information collected. This Information is collected automatically, without your interaction. It is used to improve this Website and better serve our users.

In addition to Information collected automatically, you have the opportunity to enter Information which will assist MOE in providing Educational Resources to you. Such Information includes, but is not necessarily limited to: name, age, gender, year in school, education level, educational background, relationship to current and/or prospective students, email address and geographical information such as where you reside. Except as provided in this Privacy Statement, MOE will not disclose Information that you provide through the Website to third parties.

Use and Disclosure of Information
MOE may use and disclose Information collected from and about you for the following purposes: (1) to enhance, tailor, and customize services offered on the Website; (2) to contact you directly to provide you with Educational Resources; (3) to review your use of the Website; (4) to inform organizations that provide educational services about prospective students which may result in you being contacted by such third party; (5) to compile statistical data; 6) to help establish a direct line of communication between you and colleges, universities and other institutions of higher learning; and, 7) to assist the School District of Philadelphia and other high schools attended by residents of the City of Philadelphia in providing you with resources related to your interest in pursuing post-secondary and higher education

MOE may at times share your Information with third party organizations including, but not limited to: (1) organizations under contract to act on behalf of MOE; (2) colleges, universities and other institutions of higher learning that provide post-secondary and higher education; (3) the School District of Philadelphia and other schools attended by residents of the City of Philadelphia.

Information may also be shared as required by law including, but not limited to, all applicable federal, state and local government information laws, and the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act as codified at 65 P.S. § 65.101.

Cookies
Cookies are small data files that are transferred by a web application to the user's hard drive. These files are used to store information related to the user, such as, ID, passwords etcetera. This information is provided by the user via interaction with a web application or site. Cookies do not access information on the user's computer. Their primary purpose is to make the users experience more enjoyable on there next visit to the site. Cookie management is controlled at the browser level. The user can turn off cookie transfer via the configuration option of their browser. The applications on the Website may at times transfer cookies to the user's hard drive. MOE is committed to using cookie technology responsibly and will make every effort to protect the user's computer environment from highly unlikely cookie related damage.

Security
MOE is committed to maintaining the security and integrity of personally identifiable information and other Information that is either available from or collected by the Website, and has taken reasonable precautions to protect Information from loss, misuse, alteration, or unauthorized disclosure or use. Unless a particular page on the Website states clearly that encryption technology is being used, the City cannot and does not ensure the security or confidentiality of Information uploaded through that page. The City will take reasonable precautions to safeguard the confidentiality of Information, but shall not be liable for any injury or damages arising from the disclosure of Information, whether caused by security breach or by any act or omission of the City.

Agreement
By accessing and using the Website you consent to MOE’s collection, use and disclosure of Information as described in this Privacy Statement.

item.title: City-Wide Financial Aid and FAFSA Completion Campaign
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
City-Wide Financial Aid and FAFSA Completion Campaign
PhillyGoes2College is partnering with the Federal Department of Education, the Pennsylvania Higher Education and Assistance Agency and many local organizations in a City-Wide Financial Aid and FAFSA Completion Campaign. Over 50 workshops open to students and their families will be offered to help with this effort. The FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) is the first step in the financial aid process. The FAFSA determines a student's eligibility for federal and state grants and loans. Colleges and Universities also use a student's FAFSA to create a financial aid package. All high school seniors, even if they are not sure they will attend college, should plan to complete the FAFSA as soon after January 1st as possible. The sooner students complete the FAFSA the better! Although the deadline to be eligible for Pennsylvania state grants is not until May 1st, many colleges have financial aid application deadlines in February and March, and colleges often give aid on a first come first serve basis. The FAFSA can be completed on line at www.FAFSA.gov. For help completing the FAFSA, click here to find a free workshop near you. Workshop attendees will receive hands on help completing their FAFSA.
If you can't find a workshop that works for you, you can visit a Trusted Center during designated hours for assistance. Click here to download a list of Trusted Centers.

You will need your 2010 tax information, or your parents' if you are under twenty four, for the FAFSA. You can complete the FAFSA with 2009 tax information, but will need to update it as soon as your 2010 taxes are completed. If you have not yet completed your 2010 taxes and would like help you may contact the Campaign For Working Families or visit one of their walk-in sites. They will help you complete both your taxes and your FAFSA. Click here to download a list of walk-in sites. You will need the following information to complete your FAFSA, please make sure to bring these documents to the workshop:

Your Social Security Number or Alien Registration Number if you’re not a U.S. citizen W-2 forms from the last two years Your most recent Federal Tax Income Return (as well as your parents’ tax return if you are under 24) Records of Untaxed Income (i.e., TANF, Social Security, Welfare or Veterans Benefits)

If you are interested in getting involved in FAFSA completion efforts contact the PhillyGoes2College office at 215-686-0315. Click here to download the FASFA toolkit.
If you are an adult and want more information on how to help the student in your life complete high school and prepare for college connect with the Graduation Coach Campaign.

item.title: ¿Qué es PhillyGoes2College?
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
¿Qué es PhillyGoes2College?
La oficina de PhillyGoe2College es un centro de orientación que forma parte de la Oficina de Educación de la Alcaldía el cual ayuda a los habitantes de Filadelfia, de todas las edades, a obtener un grado universitario. Cuando usted llama, envía un correo electrónico o visita la oficina, será referido a organizaciones que le ayudarán en el proceso de aplicar para la universidad. También brindamos información sobre cómo prepararse para la universidad, cómo regresar a la universidad como adulto, cómo encontrar ayuda financiera, y mucho más.
Cómo prepararse para la universidad cuando está en la escuela intermedia y secundaria Cómo planificar, recursos escolares, programas para estudiantes, y información sobre los exámenes de admisión para la universidad.
Aplicar para la universidad Como escoger una universidad.
Cómo pagar por la universidad La solicitud gratuita de ayuda federal para estudiantes (Free Application for Federal Student Aid, FAFSA), las becas, y los préstamos
Información universitaria para estudiantes adultos
Recursos para completar el GED y obtener el diploma
Aprender inglés

item.title: Aplicar para la universidad
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Aplicar para la universidad
Encontrar la universidad adecuada puede darle algo de trabajo. Afortunadamente, existen muchos sitios en Internet que permiten a los estudiantes ingresar sus intereses, puntuación del SAT, y calificaciones escolares para obtener una lista de universidades que coincidan con los criterios de cómo es la persona como estudiante.
Una vez que tenga una lista de las posibles universidades, comuníquese con las mismas para solicitar información. Siga el enlace suministrado abajo para acceder a las universidades individualmente. Recuerde considerar la universidad en su totalidad —grande o pequeña, en la ciudad o área urbana, cerca o lejos de casa, privada o institución estatal— todos estos factores deben ser considerados en su decisión sobre la universidad a la cual aplicará.
Para ingresar lo que desea y encontrar universidades que coincidan con sus intereses, vaya a www.CollegeBoard.com o www.fastweb.com.
Si desea ver una lista de todas las instituciones de educación superior y universidades en los Estados Unidos, haga clic en este enlacewww.utexas.edu/world/univ/state.
Visitar la universidad es una manera importante de averiguar si sería la adecuada para usted. Si no puede hacerle la visita a una universidad, haga una gira virtual. Entre en los siguientes sitios de Internet para ver giras virtuales: www.campustours.com , www.ecampustours.com
Si desea informarse sobre una institución de educación superior o universidad históricamente negra (conocidas regularmente como “HBCU”), haga clic aquí. Pensilvania tiene dos HBCU: Cheyney University y Lincoln University.
Si está considerando comenzar su experiencia universitaria en una institución de educación superior o técnica, asegúrese de que las clases que tome puedan ser transferidas a otras instituciones de educación superior o universidades. Averigüe qué universidades aceptan los créditos de la institución de educación superior a la que piensa asistir.
Para averiguar el calendario sobre las ferias universitarias, ingrese a www.nacacnet.org.
Si está buscando una universidad que acomoda a estudiantes con diferencias de aprendizaje o discapacidad de aprendizaje, visite Landmark College.

item.title: Cómo prepararse para la universidad cuando está en la escuela intermedia y secundaria
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Cómo prepararse para la universidad cuando está en la escuela intermedia y secundaria
Darle seguimiento a su progreso Los estudiantes que asisten a las escuelas operadas por el distrito escolar de Filadelfia pueden entrar al sitio en Internet StudentNet para ver sus calificaciones, las clases que han tomado y los resultados de exámenes. Esta puede ser una herramienta muy útil para que los estudiantes y sus padres trabajen juntos y asegurarse de que están bien encaminados para la graduación. Haga clic aquí para entrar a StudentNet.
Entérese de cómo puede ayudar a su estudiante a prepararse para la universidad KnowHow2Go ofrece información a los padres y consejeros, además de recursos para los estudiantes que cursan la escuela intermedia hasta el grado 12. Haga clic aquí para ir al sitio en Internet que le brindará consejos financieros, opciones de carreras e información sobre becas.
Planifique, prepare, decida y pague Un sitio integral en Internet que le brinda información para prepararse, aplicar y encontrar ayuda financiera para la universidad es EducationPlanner.org. Haga clic aquí para informarse cómo ellos le pueden ayudar a planificar su camino hacia la universidad.
Consejería gratuita para la universidad Los Centros de acceso universitario brindan a los estudiantes ayuda gratuita con el proceso de aplicación a la universidad, con la ayuda financiera, becas y más. Todos los estudiantes son bienvenidos a los tres lugares:
Gallery I, Street Level – Center City 9th y Market Streets 215.574.1341 Abierto lunes–jueves, 10 a. m.–6 p. m.; viernes 10 a. m.–5 p. m.
El Enterprise Center – West Philadelphia 4548 Market Street. 215.476.2227 Abierto lunes–viernes, 9 a. m.–5 p. m.
Rivera Building – North Filadelfia 2603 N. 5th Street 215.739.9360 Abierto lunes–viernes, 9 a. m.–5 p. m.
Recursos Escolares
Consejeros

Los estudiantes deben conversar con los consejeros de sus escuelas secundarias durante el primer año de secundaria (freshman year). Deben comunicarle al consejero sus planes universitarios y pedir orientación en cuanto a las clases que deben tomar para prepararse. Entre más temprano le comunican al consejero de sus planes universitarios, mejor será.
Centros para el éxito estudiantil

Además de consejeros, algunas escuelas secundarias tienen Centros para el éxito estudiantil. Estos Centros para el éxito estudiantil son otro recurso de apoyo para los estudiantes. Ofrecen consejería para la universidad y sobre carreras, al igual que apoyo académico y emocional para ayudar a que los estudiantes planifiquen sus estudios universitarios y tengan éxito en la escuela secundaria. Para enterarse si su escuela tiene un Centro para el éxito estudiantil haga clic aquí.
SAT/ACT
Muchas universidades requieren que presente la puntuación de los exámenes de admisión para la universidad cuando aplica. Hay dos exámenes de admisión para la universidad: el SAT y el ACT. En Filadelfia, más estudiantes toman el SAT que el ACT, pero es posible que usted quiera tomar ambos exámenes. Tienen diferentes formatos y algunas personas reciben mejores puntuaciones en uno o el otro. El SAT examina habilidades en matemáticas, lectura y redacción, y está dividido en varias secciones de aproximadamente veinte minutos de duración. El ACT examina habilidades en matemáticas, lectura, redacción y ciencias, y está dividido en cuatro secciones más largas. Ambos exámenes tienen una duración de aproximadamente cuatro horas.
Mientras está cursando el grado 11, tomará el PSAT (prueba de aptitud escolar), que es un examen de práctica para el SAT. Debe tomar el SAT o el ACT por primera vez durante la primavera de su penúltimo año (junior year) en la escuela secundaria. Puede tomarlos nuevamente durante su último año de escuela secundaria si sus puntuaciones no son tan buenas como le gustaría.
Tomar todos estos exámenes cuesta dinero. Sin embargo, existen excepciones del pago disponibles a través de muchos colegios secundarios y, en ocasiones, a través de las compañías que implementan los exámenes. Converse con el consejero de su escuela para obtener información sobre cómo obtener excepciones al pago. También puede obtener más información a través de los sitios en Internet de SAT y ACT sobre estas excepciones de pago.
Antes de tomar estos exámenes, debe registrarse para el SAT o el ACT por lo menos con un mes de anticipación.
Para obtener información sobre el registro en el SAT, haga clic aquí,
o aquí para información sobre el registro para el ACT.
El SAT y el ACT presentan un desafío, pero existen muchos recursos que le pueden ayudar a prepararse. Los sitios en Internet para ambos exámenes ofrecen herramientas de estudio gratuitas en línea, tales como preguntas de práctica. Muchas bibliotecas tienen copias de libros de preparatoria para el SAT y ACT, los cuales contienen información detallada, sugerencias y exámenes de práctica completos.
Muchas organizaciones en la ciudad ofrecen clases de preparatoria gratuitas para el SAT y el ACT. Puede hacer una búsqueda en nuestro calendario para encontrar una clase que le sea conveniente.
Programas después de clases y para prepararse para la universidad A Better Chance (ABC) Refiere a estudiantes de los grados 6–11 a escuelas públicas e independientes para colocaciones y ayuda financiera. Los estudiantes tienen acceso a oportunidades de educación y liderazgo. Debe aplicar a este programa para participar. 215-753-9429
ASPIRA PA Le da poder a la comunidad a través del apoyo, mediación y educación, y desarrollo de liderazgo para la juventud. Los programas ofrecen: habilitación para una carrera profesional, investigación de talento y desarrollo de liderazgo. Haga clic aquí para ver una lista de escuelas que tienen los programas ASPIRA. 215.455.1300 info@aspirapa.org
Boys and Girls Clubs Estos clubes, ubicados en varios vecindarios, ofrecen desarrollo del liderazgo, planificación de carreras y de la universidad, y oportunidades para estudiantes de la secundaria para ofrecerse como voluntarios. 215.735.8818 reception@bgcphila.org
Breakthrough of Greater Philadelphia Este programa está disponible para estudiantes de bajos recursos que cursan desde el sexto grado hasta el final de la secundaria. Consiste en programas intensivos durante el verano, programas académicos durante todo el año en los cuales se ofrecen tutorías, y programas de preparatoria universitaria diseñados para preparar a los estudiantes para la universidad. Los estudiantes deben aplicar a este programa para participar. 215-951-2398
Concerned Black Men, Inc. Ofrecen servicios para los jóvenes de ambos sexos que incluyen tutorías, preparación para el SAT, enlaces para becas y giras a instituciones de educación superior y universidades históricamente negras (Historically Black Colleges and Universities, HBCU). 215.276.2260
Congreso de Latinos Unidos Los servicios incluyen programas después de clases y al anochecer para estudiantes de secundaria, los cuales se enfocan en el desarrollo del liderazgo, servicio a la comunidad, enriquecimiento académico, y habilitación para carreras y la universidad. Congreso de Latinos Unidos se ha asociado con Harcum College para ofrecer cursos universitarios en las comunidades. 215.763.8870
Educational Advancement Alliance Ofrece programas después de clases y los sábados, enfocados al enriquecimiento académico y preparación para la universidad. También ofrecen oportunidades sociales tales como visitas a universidades y grupos de apoyo de pares. Debe aplicar a este programa para participar. 215.472.2500
Ellis Trust Los subsidios se ofrecen a niñas cursando los grados de 9–12 que vienen de familias necesitadas con un solo padre, para que puedan terminar su educación secundaria. El dinero de estos subsidios puede ser utilizado para la matrícula, clases privadas, visitas a universidades, costos de inscripción y de entrada a exámenes universitarios, cursos universitarios, programas de verano, clases de artes visuales y escénicas, etc. Debe aplicar a este programa para participar. 215.735.4483
Franklin Institute PACTS (Asociación para el logro de carreras en Tecnología y las Ciencias) es un programa de liderazgo para jóvenes con énfasis en ciencia y tecnología, ofrecido durante todo el año después de clases. También ofrecen tutoría, desarrollo de carreras profesionales y aptitudes de liderazgo. También tienen programas disponibles durante el verano. Los estudiantes de escuela intermedia y secundaria deben aplicar a este programa para participar.
Free Library of Philadelphia La biblioteca gratuita ofrece clases gratuitas durante todo el año para la preparación del SAT y ACT, y otros cursos de preparatoria para la universidad. Adicionalmente, cuentan con libros y otros recursos sobre universidades, tales como preparación para el SAT, información sobre becas, y más. Visite el sitio en Internet para encontrar una sucursal cerca de usted. También puede visitar la Parkway Central Library, ubicada entre la 19th y Vine Streets.
Police Athletic League (PAL) Las ligas mantienen a los jóvenes (niños y niñas) activos, interesados y ocupados. Brindan programas recreacionales y educativos supervisados, con el objetivo de desarrollar aptitudes de liderazgo y formar buenos ciudadanos. En sus centros alrededor de Filadelfia ofrecen programas deportivos, de liderazgo y educativos. 215-291-9000
Philadelphia Center for Arts and Technology Tienen clases disponibles para estudiantes en edades de entre 14-24 con temas que se concentran en la tecnología y las artes. Las clases enseñan aptitudes para carreras y también les brindan a los estudiantes tutoría y desarrollo del liderazgo. Los estudiantes deben aplicar a este programa para participar. 267-297-6231
Philadelphia Futures Prepara a los estudiantes de familias de bajos ingresos que asisten a las escuelas de los vecindarios de Filadelfia, para que puedan entrar y tener éxito en la universidad. Ofrecen tutoría, enriquecimiento académico, guía para la universidad, e incentivos financieros a partir del grado 9 hasta que terminen la universidad. Debe aplicar a este programa para participar. 215.790.1665
Summer Search Programa de desarrollo del liderazgo que ofrece tutoría semanal, asistencia para la preparación para la universitaria, programas de enriquecimiento durante el verano y excursiones. Los estudiantes deben aplicar a este programa para participar. 215-399-4906
Urban League of Philadelphia Ofrece oportunidades para el desarrollo del liderazgo, seminarios sobre finanzas y becas para jóvenes afroamericanos. Los estudiantes deben aplicar a este programa para participar. 215-985-3220
Upward Bound Estos programas están diseñados para preparar a estudiantes para una carrera universitaria de cuatro años. Se ofrecen a estudiantes de bajos ingresos y que son la primera generación en su familia en asistir a la universidad. Los programas son operados a través de diferentes instituciones de educación superior y universidades de la ciudad. Algunos de los programas son ofrecidos a cualquier persona de bajos ingresos, mientras que otros se ofrecen solamente a ciertas escuelas secundarias o comunidades. Debe aplicar a este programa para participar.

Community College of Philadelphia Upward Bound – 215.751.8780

Lincoln University Upward Bound – 484.365.8000 – Ofrece sesiones de tutoría y asesoría, preparación para exámenes, y un programa de verano residencial de seis semanas.

Penn State University Math and Science Upward Bound – 814.863.1296 – Ofrece un programa de verano de seis semanas que se concentra en matemáticas y ciencias, al igual que programas académicos durante todo el año.

Temple University Math and Science Upward Bound – 215.204.3636 – Se concentra en estudiantes interesados en las matemáticas y ciencias. Ofrece programas durante todo el año escolar y en el verano, además de apoyo académico y consejería.

University of Pennsylvania High School Upwards Bound – 215.898.3185 – Ofrece un programa durante todo el año comenzando en el otoño y operado por la University of Pennsylvania.
White-Williams Scholars Otorga estipendios mensuales a estudiantes dedicados que mantienen buenas notas y asisten a las escuelas secundarias de Filadelfia y que, adicionalmente, vienen de familias de bajos recursos económicos. También brinda consejería para la universidad, giras a las universidades y grupos de apoyo de pares. Debe aplicar a este programa para participar. 215.735.4480
WorkReady Ofrece pasantías pagadas y trabajos durante el verano a estudiantes de escuela secundaria, al igual que programas de tutoría para carreras profesionales y oportunidades de aprendizaje por observación de trabajos. Los estudiantes deben aplicar a este programa para participar. 267-502-3742
YMCA Achievers Program Ofrece tutoría para carreras y enriquecimiento académico para jóvenes que cursan los grados de 7 a 12. 215-235-6550

item.title: FAFSA
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
FAFSA
La solicitud gratuita de ayuda federal para estudiantes (Free Application for Federal Student Aid, FAFSA) es el primer paso en el proceso de búsqueda de ayuda financiera. La FAFSA determina la elegibilidad del estudiante con relación a subsidios y préstamos federales y estatales. Las instituciones de educación superior y las universidades también utilizan la FAFSA para crear un paquete de ayuda financiera.
Todos los estudiantes en su último año de escuela secundaria, aunque no estén seguros de que irán a la universidad, deben tener dentro de sus planes completar la FAFSA lo antes posible después del 1 de enero. ¡Entre más pronto complete la FAFSA, será mejor! Aunque la fecha límite para ser elegible para subsidios estatales en el estado de Pensilvania no es sino hasta el 1 de mayo, muchas universidades tienen fechas límites para la aplicación de ayuda financiera, las cuales son en febrero y marzo. Además, muchas universidades otorgan la ayuda, con frecuencia, en base al orden de llegada.
Puede completar la FAFSA en www.FAFSA.gov. Para obtener ayuda para completar la FAFSA, haga clic aquí para encontrar un seminario gratuito cercano a usted. Los que asisten al seminario recibirán ayuda interactiva para completar su FAFSA.
Para llenar el formulario de la FAFSA, necesitará su información de impuestos del año 2010, o la de sus padres si tiene menos de veinticuatro años Puede completar la FAFSA con información de impuestos del 2009, pero necesitará actualizarla apenas tenga preparada la declaración de impuestos del 2010. Si aún no ha completado su declaración de impuestos del 2010 y le gustaría obtener ayuda, puede comunicarse con Campaign For Working Families, o visitar uno de sus locales a los que puede llegar sin previa cita. Ellos le ayudarán a completar tanto su declaración de impuestos como su FAFSA. Haga clic aquí para descargar una lista de los lugares a los que puede visitar.
Necesitará la siguiente información para completar su FAFSA, y asegúrese de llevar estos documentos al seminario:

Su número de seguro social o número de tarjeta de inmigrante, si no es ciudadano de los EE. UU.

Su formulario W-2 de los últimos dos años

Declaración de Impuesto sobre la renta más reciente (al igual que la de sus padres si es menor de 24)

Registros de ingresos exonerados de impuestos (es decir, Programa de ayuda temporal para familias necesitadas (TANF), Seguro Social, el programa de asistencia social (Welfare), o Beneficios para Veteranos)
Si está interesado en participar en los esfuerzos de ayuda para completar la FAFSA, comuníquese con la oficina de PhillyGoes2College al 215-686-0315. Haga clic aquí para descargar el conjunto de herramientas de la FAFSA.
Créditos tributarios para la universidad
American Opportunity Tax Credit ofrece una deducción de hasta $2,500 para gastos universitarios. Para calificar para este crédito, debe tener ingresos menores de $80,000 si declara como persona soltera, o menos de $160,000 si declara como persona casada. El crédito de $2,500 puede ser reclamado por los padres por cada hijo que está asistiendo a la universidad o, si el estudiante declara sus impuestos como persona independiente, el crédito lo puede reclamar el estudiante.
Becas para residentes de Filadelfia
CORE Philly ofrece becas Last Dollar de hasta $2,000 a estudiantes en el último año de la escuela secundaria para cubrir necesidades financieras que no han sido cubiertas para el primer año de universidad. El único requisito de elegibilidad es estar matriculado en una institución de educación superior o técnica en Filadelfia, o en cualquier universidad o institución de educación superior estatal en Pensilvania. Para obtener una lista de instituciones elegibles, visite el sitio en Internet.
Philadelphia City Scholarship Program ofrece la suma de $1,000/año para asistir a una universidad localizada en el área metropolitana de Filadelfia.
Center for Student Opportunity le permite a los estudiantes crear un perfil para buscar becas y recibir información pertinente sobre la universidad. Al crear un perfil también tiene la oportunidad de ser elegible para aplicar a una beca que ofrecen.
Philadelphia Foundation administra varias becas diferentes destinadas para estudiantes en Filadelfia. Puede ver la lista de becas y descargar las aplicaciones en los sitios de Internet de las mismas.
Philadelphia Scholars Fund ofrece becas a estudiantes de escuelas secundarias de Filadelfia que han participado en Programas de acceso universitario en una de las veintiún escuelas secundarias públicas de Filadelfia. Entre en el sitio de Internet para averiguar si su escuela es elegible.
Urban League of Philadelphia ofrece varias becas que incluyen el programa Community Scholarship Program y la beca American Association of Blacks in Energy/Urban League of Philadelphia Scholarship. Para obtener más información sobre becas llame al 215-985-3220, ext. 208.
Becas para universidades e instituciones de educación superior locales
El Community College of Philadelphia ofrece la beca Robert S. King Scholarship a estudiantes elegibles que se gradúan de una escuela secundaria localizada dentro de la ciudad de Filadelfia. Para obtener más información, comuníquese con Patti Conroy al 215.751.8214 o al correo electrónico: pconroy@ccp.edu.
Drexel Liberty Scholars ofrece becas para el pago completo de la matrícula a estudiantes de Filadelfia de bajos ingresos y es renovable anualmente.
Philadelphia Scholars Award ofrecida por Harrisburg University of Science and Technology, es una beca que ofrece el pago completo de la matrícula y es renovable durante cuatro años para los estudiantes de Filadelfia.
Peirce College ofrece la Beca del Alcalde a un residente de Filadelfia y a un empleado de la ciudad de Filadelfia cada año. Esta beca cubre el pago completo de la matrícula y es renovable anualmente. Para aplicar, presente su aplicación adjuntando la composición y los otros documentos descritos aquí.
Penn State Alumni Association Scholarship está disponible para los alumnos de Filadelfia que están cursando el primer año universitario y que están asistiendo a cualquier universidad estatal de Pensilvania. Becas de $1,000 cada una se le otorgan a dos estudiantes. La aplicación para las mismas tiene una fecha límite del 1 de octubre, 2010.
Programa de Becas del Alcalde a través de la University of Pennsylvania cubre todas las necesidades financieras y es renovable durante cuatro años.
Sitios en Internet para ayudarlo a encontrar becas
El Distrito escolar de Filadelfia clasifica las becas en listas de acuerdo a las fechas topes para aplicar. Este es un buen lugar para comenzar si se está sintiendo abrumado con los buscadores que enseñan listas de cientos de becas. ¡No tiene que asistir a una escuela dentro del Distrito escolar de Filadelfia para utilizar este sitio!
CollegeBoard, Education Planner, y FastWeb le ofrecen buscadores para la investigación detallada de becas, y le permiten guardar un perfil e ingresar información de todo lo que desee, desde sus calificaciones escolares hasta sus afecciones médicas. Los buscadores utilizan esta información para encontrar becas que son las apropiadas para usted.
United Negro College Fund tiene un buscador de becas y también le permite ver listas de becas con fechas topes que se están aproximando.
ASPIRA ofrece una lista de becas en su sitio de Internet.
Scholarships 4 Students ofrece una lista de becas según categorías. Tiene una lista para estudiantes de escuelas secundarias, una lista para estudiantes que están actualmente en la universidad, una lista por especialización de estudios en la universidad, etc.
Préstamos
Los préstamos para estudiantes puede ser el último recurso para lograr la diferencia entre lo que usted puede pagar y la asistencia financiera que recibe del gobierno, de su universidad y de las becas privadas. Conseguir un préstamo puede ser un proceso intimidante, pero una gran mayoría de estudiantes tienen que pedir prestado, por lo menos una pequeña cantidad, para pagar la universidad. Existe un programa de préstamos federales exclusivamente para estudiantes el cual ofrece préstamos con intereses bajos que no tiene que pagarlos sino hasta después que termina la universidad. Si tiene que pedir prestado, su primera opción debe ser los préstamos federales.
Existen dos tipos de préstamos federales para estudiantes: subsidiado y no subsidiado. Para averiguar a cuál de estos usted es elegible, debe completar la FAFSA; información de la FAFSA se incluye en la parte superior de esta página. Si su préstamo es subsidiado, esto significa que el gobierno pagará los intereses que se cargan a su préstamo mientras está en la universidad. Cuando sale de la universidad, solamente será responsable por el monto exacto que pidió prestado. Si su préstamo no es subsidiado, usted será responsable de pagar los intereses que se cargan a su préstamo, al igual que el monto original que pidió prestado.
Los padres también pueden solicitar préstamos para ayudar a pagar los gastos educativos de sus estudiantes, a través del programa federal Parent PLUS loan program. Al igual que los préstamos federales para estudiantes, los préstamos Parent PLUS ofrecen intereses más bajos que los préstamos bancarios.
Indulgencia de un préstamo

Si planea entrar al servicio público, como la docencia o trabajar para el gobierno, podría ser elegible para el Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program. Este programa ofrece la indulgencia de préstamos a personas que han trabajado en puestos de servicio público por diez años mientras pagaban sus préstamos. Después de diez años de haber realizado 120 pagos, se le exonera al prestatario el balance de los pagos. Para contar a favor de los 120 pagos, los pagos debieron haber sido realizados después de octubre del 2007.

item.title: Información universitaria para estudiantes adultos
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Información universitaria para estudiantes adultos
Haga clic aquí para información para estudiantes adultos sobre la planificación de la educación superior.
Graduate! Philadelphia
Si usted es un adulto que tiene algunos créditos universitarios y desea completar su título universitario, puede conectarse con Graduate! Philadelphia. Ellos le brindarán guía gratuita y apoyo para que vuelva a la universidad y continuarán con usted hasta que se gradúe.
Su oficina principal está localizada en The Gallery I, Street Level – Center City, entre la 9th y Market Streets,

Teléfono: 215-574-1341.

Abierto los lunes, jueves, viernes 10 AM – 5 PM; martes y viernes 10 AM – 7 PM.

Visitas sin previa cita son bienvenidas: lunes, viernes 10 AM – 2 PM; martes, miércoles 3 PM – 7 PM.
Centro de oportunidades educativas
Si es un estudiante de 19 años de edad o más y desea ir a la universidad, o tiene algunos créditos universitarios y desea completar si carrera universitaria, puede conectarse al Centro de oportunidades educativas:

Educational Opportunity Center – Penn State University.

Educational Opportunity Center – University of Pennsylvania– Solamente para estudiantes de West Philadelphia.
Un recurso sólo para veteranos

Si usted es un veterano, hay un programa llamado Veterans Upward Bound que puede ayudarlo a prepararse académicamente para la universidad, y ofrece apoyo continuo mientras avanza para obtener su grado universitario.

Para obtener información sobre el programa, llame al 215.898.6892. Comuníquese con ellos para averiguar si es elegible.
Returning to Learning Partnership

Al escoger una universidad, los empleados de la Ciudad de Filadelfia deben considerar aquellas universidades que son miembros de la asociación Returning to Learning Partnership. Este programa ofrece a los empleados de la ciudad un descuento en la matrícula del 25% en las siguientes instituciones asociadas: Chestnut Hill College, Community College de Philadelphia, Peirce College, Philadelphia University, Rosemont College, Neumann University y Widener University. Consulte el calendario de PhillyGoes2College para enterarse de fechas y lugares donde se llevarán a cabo próximamente las sesiones informativas. Haga clic aquí para descargar el hoja de datos del descuento para empleados.

item.title: Recursos para completar el GED y obtener el diploma
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Recursos para completar el GED y obtener el diploma
La Comisión de Alfabetización promulgada por el Alcalde

Si es un estudiante que desea asistir a la universidad, pero antes debe completar el GED (Desarrollo educativo general), puede comunicarse con la Comisión de Alfabetización en la alcaldía al 215-686-5250, para obtener información sobre los programas del GED.
Re-Engagement Center del Distrito escolar de Filadelfia

El Distrito escolar opera un Re-Engagement Center que ofrece recursos a estudiantes entre las edades 16-21 que necesitan ayuda para obtener su diploma de escuela secundaria o el GED.

Puede visitarlos en el primer piso del edificio del Distrito escolar en 440 N. Broad Street, de lunes a viernes 7:30 AM – 6 PM 215-400-6700 reengagementcenter@philasd.org
Reader Development Program de la Free Library of Philadelphia

Este programa ofrece a los estudiantes adultos alfabetización gratuita, el GED, preparación para el GED y libros para aprender inglés como segundo idioma (ESL). Si está estudiando para el GED o trabajando para mejorar sus aptitudes de lectura, llame al 215-686-5346 de lunes a viernes 9 a. m.-5 p. m., para averiguar cómo puede tomar ventaja de este recurso.
Philadelphia Youth Network (PYN) E3 Centers

Existen cinco centros diseñados para ofrecer educación, trabajo y recursos de fortalecimiento para jóvenes que no están en la escuela y están desconectados del aprendizaje, entre las edades 14-24. Haga clic aquí para averiguar las ubicaciones e información de contacto.

item.title: Aprender inglés
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Aprender inglés
Centros de alfabetización

Para averiguar más información sobre clases de ESL, póngase en contacto a través del correo electrónico o llame al 215-474-1235.
Reader Development Program de la Free Library of Philadelphia

Este programa ofrece a los estudiantes adultos alfabetización gratuita, el GED, preparación para el GED y libros para aprender inglés como segundo idioma (ESL). Si está estudiando para el GED o trabajando para mejorar sus aptitudes de lectura, llame al 215-686-5346 de lunes a viernes 9 a. m.-5 p. m., para averiguar cómo puede tomar ventaja de este recurso.
Latino Community Learning Center

Este centro ofrece clases para la educación de adultos en ESL, para el GED en español o GED en inglés.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickies to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Free SAT Prep Class
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Is it your first time taking the SATs and you want to know what to expect? Have you taken the SATs before and you want to do better? Then come and find out inside information from an experienced SAT instructor and learn how to improve your scores!
Classes are FREE and open to all high school students. Space is limited: registration is required. To register, please email collegeprep@freelibrary.org with your full name, phone number, & the date of the session you want to attend, or call 215-686-5372 between 9am-5pm, Monday-Friday!
For more information about the College Prep Program, email collegeprep@freelibrary.org or call (215)686-5372.

item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Scholarship Essay Writing Clinic
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
College Students will work one-on-one with participants to craft an essay for a scholarship or college application. Students may come to the event with a scholarship in mind, or work on an essay for a scholarship recomended by the writing clinic. Students may bring a rough draft or begin an essay at the workshop.
Dinner will be provided.
Please RSVP by calling 215-686-0315, or emailing info@phillygoes2college.com
The event will take place at Temple University in Computer Lab 9 of the Tuttleman Learning Center. Tuttleman is located at the northeast corner of 13th and Montgomery.

Parkway Central Library, 1901 Vine Street (9:30 AM - 12:30 PM) Widener Branch, 2808 West Lehigh Avenue (1 PM - 4 PM) Joseph E. Coleman Northwest Regional Library, 68 W Chelten Avenue (1 PM - 4 PM) Northeast Regional Library, 2228 Cottman Avenue (1 PM -4 PM)

item.title: NACAC College Fair for Performing and Visual Arts
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The Performing and Visual Arts (PVA) College Fairs are designed for students interested in pursuing undergraduate and graduate study in the areas of music, dance, theater, visual arts, graphic design, and other related disciplines.
The fair will take place at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.
Use this checklist, provided by NACAC, to make the most of the fair: http://www.nacacnet.org/EventsTraining/CollegeFairs/ncf/Documents/CollegeFairChecklist.pdf

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: PA Academy for the Fine Arts

item.title: NACAC Philadelphia National College Fair
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This annual college fair brings representatives from colleges and universites from all over the country to Philadelphia. This is a great opportunity to find out more about colleges you are interested in and learn about others you have never heard of.
Visit the website to learn more and register in advance (registration is free!): http://www.nacacnet.org/EventsTraining/CollegeFairs/ncf/Fall/Pages/10FPhi.aspx
Find out how to make the most out of the fair: http://www.nacacnet.org/EventsTraining/CollegeFairs/ncf/students/Pages/NCFTips.aspx

item.title: Free College Application Workshop
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This free clinic will offer one-on-one help for high school seniors working on college applications. High school seniors will be matched with college students for help working on whatever section of the application they need help with.   If you have already begun to work on an application bring a draft for help editing. If you haven't started, don't worry! A tutor will help you figure out how to begin. Lunch will also be provided!
Online Ticketing for College Application Essay Writing Clinic powered by Eventbrite

item.title: Returning to Learning:A College Fair for Adults
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
If you are over 19 and:
-have some college credits and want to complete your degree, -have an associate's degree and want to complete a 4-year degree, -or have no college experience at all but want to start college
This FREE college fair is for you!
Explore options, interview college representatives, and learn how you can complete your degree at local colleges.

For more information contact the Nicetown CDC at 215-329-1824 or 215-549-3651

item.title: Perfecting the College Essay, Session I
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Whether you've already started a draft or you're just beginning the process, join Spells Writing Lab and current college students from Ursinus College for a two-week session that will set you on the right track. The workshop will provide you with general preparation for the college application writing process and allow you to work in small groups and one-on-one with current college students who will help you with your writing!
Session I: September 26 and October 3 from 1-3 PM (students will be expect to attend both classes)
Class size is limited to 10 students. To register, please email write@phillyspells.org or call 267-670-0869.

item.title: Perfecting The College Essay, Session II
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Whether you've already started a draft or you're just beginning the process, join Spells Writing Lab and current college students from Ursinus College for a two-week session that will set you on the right track. The workshop will provide you with general preparation for the college application writing process and allow you to work in small groups and one-on-one with current college students who will help you with your writing!
Session II: November 6 and 13 from 3-5 PM (students will be expected to attend both classes)
Class size is limited to 10 students. To register, please email write@phillyspells.org or call 267-670-0869.

item.title: Perfecting the College Essay, Session III
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Whether you've already started a draft or you're just beginning the process, join Spells Writing Lab and current college students from Ursinus College for a two-week session that will set you on the right track. The workshop will provide you with general preparation for the college application writing process and allow you to work in small groups and one-on-one with current college students who will help you with your writing!
Session III: November 7 and 14 from 1-3 PM (students will be expected to attend both classes)
Class size is limited to 10 students. To register, please email write@phillyspells.org or call 267-670-0869.

item.title: Creating the College Essay
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Join local writing teacher Kate Rettaliata for a four-week course that will walk you through each step of the college essay writing process. Using creative, interesting activities aimed at unleashing your personal story you will learn more about yourself and how to best present yourself in your essay. The workshop will include individual meeting time with Kate and other volunteers who will give one-on-one feedback on your writing each week. October 5, 12, 19, 26 from 3:30-5 PM (students will be expected to attend all classes) Class limited to 12 students. To register, please email write@phillyspells.org or call 267-670-0869.

item.content:encoded:

Classes are FREE and open to all high school students. Space is limited: registration is required. To register, please email collegeprep@freelibrary.org with your full name, phone number, & the date of the session you want to attend, or call 215-686-5372 between 9am-5pm, Monday-Friday!

item.title: 8 Week SAT Prep Workshop
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This small group SAT prep class will include eight 2-hour sessions. Classes will take place Wednesday evenings 6 - 8 PM, October 13 - December 15. There will be no class November 24th.
The total cost is $280. This will include all eight classes and a SAT prep book.
Call Billy Eisenber at 267-254-1787, or email at billy.eisenberg@gmail.com for more information.

item.title: College Planning for Students with Learning Differences
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Join Rachel B Sobel, Ph. D, College Possibilities, LLC to learn about the best college option for your student with learning differences. Find out what support they are entitled to and which colleges will best accommodate their needs.
Dinner will be provided and a gift card will be raffled off.

item.title: College Prep Night
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This event is for middle and high school students and their parents. There will be workshops on financing college, college students sharing their experiences, and an academic program fair featuring opportunities for students to get involved. Two $529 savings plan scholarships will be raffled off and dinner will be provided.
How to Finance College – Panel Discussion 6 pm – 7:30 pm
College Prep Activities Fair 7 pm – 8 pm
College Student Panel - college students will share their experiences with middle and high school students. 6 pm – 8 pm

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Community College of Philadelphia, Winnet Student Life Building, S219

item.title: Everything Adults Need To Know About Going To College
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Come learn about how to pay for college and fit classes into your busy life. Dinner will be provided and a gift card will be raffled off.

item.title: College Application Workshop
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Get hands on help with your college application! Open to high school seniors, registration is required. Registration is different for this workshop! We are excited to expand options for students with this workshop, but it has made registration more complicated. If you have questions about registration please call the office, 215-686-0315. If you are starting the college application process or would like one-on-one help with your application, register for one-on-one application assistance. If you are looking for help with the essay portion of your application register for the college application essay writing workshop. Please register for only one of these workshops! For one-on-one application assistance click here. For college application essay writing workshop click here.

item.title: Cheyney University's Fall Open House
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: High school students and their parents are welcome to attend this free open house at Cheyney University. Open House Schedule 9 AM - 10 AM : Registration in Cope Hall Gymnasium 10 AM - 11 AM: Welcome session 11 AM - 12 PM: Campus Tours 12 PM - 1 PM: Academic/Student Service Fair 1 PM - 2 PM: Lunch and Entertainment 2 PM - until: On-site Admissions. You are encouraged to bring a complete application, official high school transcript, SAT or ACT scores, 2 letters of recommendation and the $20 application fee for a decision on site. For more information please call 610-399-2275 or 1-800-CHEYNEY ext 2275

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Join Councilwoman Jannie Blackwell, the Educational Opportunity Center and the West Philadelphia YMCA for this college fair just for adults from Southwest and West Philadelphia who are interested in going to college.
Attendees will learn how to find grants and financial aid and find information on accelerated degrees, online classes, night time classes and GED to college programs. Attendees will also receive a free trial membership to the West Philadelphia YMCA.
Call 215-573-8000 to register for the fair.

item.title: Rosemont College Financial Aid Information Session for Adult Students
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The purpose of this presentation is to inform adult students about the process of preparing for the financial aspects of returning to college both at the undergraduate and graduate levels. Specific topics directed specifically to the adult student include:
• Determining the total cost of attendance • The FAFSA process • Deferring your loans • The Federal Direct loan process and loan limits • Loan Repayment options • Availability of discounts and grants • Education tax credits • Financial return on your educational investment
To confirm attendance or ask questions in advance, please e-mail cwalz@rosemont.edu.

item.title: November 17th College Application Workshop
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Get ready for December and January college application deadlines! This free workshop will offer high school seniors one-on-one help with their college applications. College student tutors will provide assistance no matter where you are in the college application process. If you have already begun to work on your application or essay bring a draft for editing. If you haven't started, don't worry! A tutor will help you figure out how to begin. Registration is required, please register here or by calling 215-686-0315.

item.title: Creating a college going culture in schools conference
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This conference is open to students, teachers, parents and mentors interested in learning about ways to encourage college going within schools. The day will include a number of different workshops on topics from "creating a plan for the community college-bound student" to "STOP the violence! Your future is worth it!"

item.title: Free FAFSA Workshop: Rhodes High School
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Come to this free workshop for helping completing the FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid). The FASFA must be completed in order to apply for most types of financial aid. High school seniors and their parents should complete it as soon after January 1st as possible. Call PhillyGoes2College at 215-686-0315 for more information.
You will need the following information to complete your FAFSA, please make sure to bring these documents to the workshop: Your Social Security Number or Alien Registration Number if you’re not a U.S. citizen W-2 forms from the last two years Your most recent Federal Tax Income Return (as well as your parents’ tax return if you are under 24) Records of Untaxed Income (i.e., TANF, Social Security, Welfare or Veterans Benefits)

item.title: Neumann University Information Session for City of Philadelphia Employees
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We are pleased to update you on the recently formed partnership between the City of Philadelphia and Neumann University. City employees, their spouses and their dependents who meet all admissions requirements are able to receive a 25% tuition discount on credit courses in degree completion programs and Master's degree programs offered by the Division of Continuing Adult and Professional Studies. The tuition discount also applies to Master's degree programs offered through other divisions of Neumann University.
Come learn about this exciting opportunity at an information session on December 15, 2010

item.title: College and Scholarship Application Workshop
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Prepare for college application deadlines and get a head start on scholarships! This free workshop will offer high school seniors one-on-one help with their college and scholarship applications. College student tutors will provide assistance no matter where you are in the college or scholarship application process. If you have already started to work on your application or essay bring a draft for editing. If you haven't, don't worry! A tutor will help you figure out how to begin. Registration is required, click here to register or call 215-686-0315

item.title: How to pay for college: a free workshop
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Thinking about going to college but not sure how to pay for it? Want to help the high school student in your life go to college but don’t think you can afford to? Please join us to answer these questions and more and find out how college may be more affordable than you think. In partnership with Philly Goes 2 College, United Way of Southeastern Pennsylvania will be hosting two workshops in celebration of the Martin Luther King, Jr. Day on January 17, 2011 at Girard College. Each workshop will last for about an hour and will take place twice, at 9:30am and again at 11:00 am. SESSION 1: HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS ONLY How to pay for college: A Student’s Perspective is for high school students considering college. College students from various schools in the Philadelphia area will breakdown college tuition costs and discuss resources available to students to assist in defraying tuition costs such as scholarships, loans and grants. To attend this workshop, sign up at http://astudentsperspective.eventbrite.com SESSION 2: PARENTS, GUARDIANS & ADULTS ASSISTING HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS How to pay for college: Navigating the FAFSA and other financial resources is geared specifically for adults who are looking to help the high school student in their life afford a college education. A panel of experts will discuss the difference between public and private loans, tax benefits for adults supporting college students, grant and scholarship resources, and the importance of competing FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid). If you’re interested in attending this workshop, sign up at http://navigatingthefafsa.eventbrite.com

item.title: Free SAT Prep Class
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Is it your first time taking the SATs and you want to know what to expect? Have you taken the SATs before and you want to do better? Then come and find out inside information from an experienced SAT instructor and learn how to improve your scores!
Classes are FREE and open to all high school students. Space is limited: registration is required. To register, please email collegeprep@freelibrary.org with your full name, phone number, & the date of the session you want to attend, or call 215-686-5372 between 9am-5pm, Monday-Friday!
For more information about the College Prep Program, email collegeprep@freelibrary.org or call (215)686-5372.

item.title: Free FAFSA Completion Assistance
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Anyone who needs help completing the FAFSA (Free Application for Federal Student Aid) may come to these free walk-in hours. The FASFA must be completed in order to apply for most types of financial aid. High school seniors and their parents should complete it as soon after January 1st as possible. Call PhillyGoes2College at 215-686-0315 for more information. FAFSA Completion Walk-in Hours will take place at the following locations: PHEAA - 215 S. Broad St 2nd Floor Rear, 215-735-2877: Mon - Fri, 10 AM - 5 PM Columbia North YMCA - 1400 N. Broad St, 215-235-6440: Mon - Fri, 1 PM - 6 PM West Philadelphia YMCA - 5120 Chestnut St, 215-476-2700: Mon - Fri, 1 PM - 6 PM College Access North - The Rivera Building, 2603 N. 5th St, 215-739-9360: Mon - Fri, 9 AM - 5 PM College Access Center City - The Gallery I Street Level, 9th and Market St: Mon - Fri, 9 AM - 5 PM College Access West - The Enterprise Center, 4548 Market St: Mon - Fri, 9 AM - 5 PM Bryn Athen College - Swedenborg Library, 2945 College Dr, Bryn Athen, 267- 502-6033: Weds, 5 - 8 PM You will need the following information to complete your FAFSA, please make sure to bring these documents with you: Your Social Security Number or Alien Registration Number if you’re not a U.S. citizen W-2 forms from the last two years Your most recent Federal Tax Income Return (and your parents’ tax return if you are under 24) Records of Untaxed Income (i.e., TANF, Social Security, Welfare or Veterans Benefits)

item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:

Through symbolic representation via collage and creative charting techniques, participants will set and design their goals to see them to fruition. This 2-hour workshop allows students in the 9th and 10th grade to begin taking action steps towards creating their future.

item.dc:creator: admin

This parent-led seminar will provide information about scholarships, financial aid forms, and other resources to help you begin. Parents with students in the 10th & 11th grade will receive first preference for admission to this workshop.
To register please contact: 267-324-5600 or bluesbabefoundation@gmail.com

Participants will also receive a copy of the book Higher Learning: Maximizing Your College Experience.

item.title: Free Scholarship Application Workshop!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Prepare for college application deadlines and get a head start on scholarships! This free workshop will offer high school students hands on help with their college and scholarship applications. College student tutors will provide assistance no matter where you are in the college or scholarship application process. If you have already started to work on your application or essay bring a draft for editing. If you haven't, don't worry! A tutor will help you figure out how to begin. Registration is required, please register below.
Event Registration Online for College and Scholarship Application Workshop powered by Eventbrite

item.title: Computer and Information Expo
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This free day long event open to any parents with students in the School District of Philadelphia will feature free workshops on a variety of topics as well as free breakfast and childcare.
Please register by calling 215-400-4180 or by visiting www.philasd.org/parentuniversity
Free Computer Classes for Beginner and Advanced Users on the follow topics: • Computer buying tips • Internet Safety • Browsing the Internet • Check your child’s grades & attendance (Bring your child’s student ID) • Create a flyer with Microsoft Word • Get a FREE e-mail address • Create your own web page for FREE • Painting with your computer
Free classes for parents on: • A Future of Fortune: Careers in Science, Technology, Engineering & Math • Understanding College Athletic Scholarships • Preparing Your Child to Attend College • Know your Rights as a Title I Parent with PREP (Parents ‘R’ Equal Partners)

item.title: Cheyney University "First Choice Day"
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
You are invited to attend the Cheyney University “First Choice Day” on Saturday, April 30th from 10am to 1pm in the Carnegie Hall Great Room, which is located on the University’s historic main campus. At this event, you will be able to take advantage of the following enrollment opportunities : 1. On-site admission, 2. Submission of outstanding, required admissions credentials (transcripts and SAT/ACT scores), 3. General admissions counseling, and 4. Financial Aid literacy.
Refreshments and prizes available.
TRANSFER STUDENTS with 12 transferrable credits should bring official transcripts from all institutions of higher education they've attended for an immediate decision for Summer 2011 & or Fall 2011.
For more information call 610-399-2275 or 610-399-2102

item.title: Financial Aid Night
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Looking for help figuring out how to pay for college? It can be confusing to make the jump into college – Which school is right for you? How will you pay for it? Come to this free event to learn the skills that are essential to getting into college and staying there. This event will give you group and one-on-one opportunities to learn more about your next steps for college enrollment and financial planning. Presented by the Financial Aid U initiative, a program of the Campaign for Working Families, National Community Tax Coalition, PhillyGoes2College, Citi Foundation and PricewaterhouseCoopers.
This event will offer useful information if you are planning to enroll in college next fall and have not applied to a college, have not decided which college to attend, or are still trying to figure out how you will pay for college. Bring anything you have questions about. If you have award letters from colleges that describe your financial aid package, it’s helpful to bring those along.
To RSVP email wdingle@uac.org or call 215-851-1745.

item.title: Drexel University Information Session for City Employees
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
City of Philadelphia employees are welcome to attend this information session to learn about Drexel's 25% tuition discount, offered through the Mayor's Returning to Learning Partnership. Full-time city employees who meet all admissions requirements are able to receive a 25% tuition discount on part-time programs at Drexel University's Goodwin College of Professional Studies.
For application information, contact Matthew Gray at 215-895-6255 or mdg67@drexel.edu.

item.title: Leadership Training Program for Young Women
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Federally Employed Women (FEW) is offering a day of workshops and training for young women who will be entering their Junior or Senior year of high school in fall 2011. Workshops will include financial planning, career advice, and interviewing skills. Registration is required.
Contact Joyce Hageman at 575 644-6183 or jkhageman35@gmail.com for more information or to register.

item.title: Five Most Important Steps to Take If You Want To Go To College
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
1. If you’re in 9th grade, you should start to plan ahead NOW to choose the high school classes you will need to get into the college of your choice. Check with your college guidance counselor to make sure you’re on the right track.
  2. If you are in high school, you’ll need to take a college admission test to get admitted to college. Take the PSATs (which is a practice test), prior to taking the SAT or ACT test. Check out the Free Library near you for resources to study for the tests. They have books to help you study and also provide free SAT prep classes throughout the year. They provide free SAT prep classes and basic college prep workshops throughout the year.
  3. Paying for college is sometimes the biggest challenge for all students – whether you’re currently in school or not. You need to plan for how to pay for college way before you enroll.
  4. If you need financial aid, the first step is to complete the FAFSA form (which stands for the Free Application for Federal Student Aid) to find out how much money you are eligible to receive to go to college. You can find information on organizations that can help by clicking here.
  5. Ask for help! Going to college can be confusing. People want to help. If you don’t ask for guidance, you will never get it! There are on-line resources you can get through on this website by clicking here.

item.title: The Young People's Computer Center
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The Young People's Computer Center offers a community space and computer access for youth. Over the summer they will also be offering workshops on finding a summer job and getting ready for college at 1 PM every Thursday. The center is on the 2nd floor at 4205 Chestnut St and is open Monday-Thursday, 11 AM - 5 PM. For more information email chris@mediamobilizing.org or call 215-253-4586.
